talk.start.para: âThe issue I want to talk about tonight is becoming a very serious matter for many Australian families. These are families who are struggling following this government's progressive dismantling of assistance to people with disabilities. We have a situation now in Australia where levels of unmet need for disability services are rising. Some 13,500 people with severe and profound disabilities do not get the accommodation services that they need, about 30,000 people with disabilities do not get the help with employment assistance that they need and 7,700 people with severe and profound disabilities are cared for by parents who are aged over 65. The important point about these figures that everybody needs to be aware of is that these people are people with severe and profound disabilities who do not have decent accommodation or who are living with parents who are getting much older. The need in accommodation services alone has been costed at $275 million by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare.

speech.para: What has been the government's response to this increasing need? The government's response has been as follows. First of all, they cut $174 million from the disability services budget over the last two budgets. So, in the face of this dire need, what do this government do? They cut $174 million from the budget. They did not even have the decency to tell people with disabilities that they were cutting the budget, preferring to call the lion's share of the cuts `efficiency dividends'. These efficiency dividends are in fact, of course, significant cuts.

Secondly, this government has failed to sign the Commonwealth-state disability agreements after three token offers which the states and territories have found very easy to reject. This failure has put disability services into limbo, unable to plan for the future, existing from month to month. This is because the states and territories know that the Commonwealth offer goes nowhere near meeting the needs that have been outlined above. The National Council on Intellectual Disability condemned and rejected outright the latest offer made by the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) last week to the states and territories, calling it a totally inadequate offer and saying this:

Given the Prime Minister's recent promise, [the National Council on Intellectual Disability] strongly criticises the Federal Government for its insult to people with disability and their families that this offer represents.

The next area where the government is taking cuts out of those families that have children with disabilities is that the government is taking the child disability allowance away from families. About 8,000 children, according to Senate estimates last week, will lose the child disability allowance as a result of the government changing the definition of who is disabled. After June 1998, when the new assessment tables come in, the government has budgeted for savings of $25.3 million in the 1998-99 financial year alone. In one year alone $25 million will be taken off children with a disability. It has also abolished the position of the Disability Discrimination Commissioner.

Most important of all is what the government is doing to people with disabilities who are trying to get work. The unemployment rate for people with a disability is more than double what it is for the rest of the population. To give people with disabilities the same chances for jobs and decent wages that other Australians have, there used to be specific labour market programs specifically designed to meet their needs. These were called the disability reform panels, and they were successful. The latest review of them showed that clearly. Once again, what has this government done? This government has abolished them. It has abolished something that worked and replaced it with an experiment: the new labour market arrangements that come into place in May this year. What this will mean for people with disabilities who are trying to get back to work is still unclear. But what does seem to be clear is that it will be left up to people with disabilities to find their own way through what will be a much more complicated maze of employment support.

I make a final point as far as this litany of reduction in support by this government and failure to support people with disabilities is concerned. Late last year we saw the government trying to take away the mobility allowance from people with intellectual disabilities who attend independent living skills centres. This was never announced; it just happened. Gradually the phone calls started coming in and then more and more phone calls and letters were coming in from people saying that they had lost their mobility allowance. This meant that people were not going to be able to afford to pay for the transport that was required to get them to these independent living centres. Fortunately, as a result of considerable pressure on the government, this latest attack on people with disabilities was headed off. It is pleasing to be able to say that mobility allowance looks safe for the moment. Nevertheless, given the litany of attacks that people with disabilities have suffered under this government, nobody could be too sure.

The 1980s, I am pleased to say, was a period of considerable reform in the disability area. The Disability Services Act was passed in 1986, followed by the first Commonwealth-state disability agreement and then the Disability Discrimination Act. It was a period when we spoke regularly about the breaking down of barriers. But what this government is doing is progressively erecting the barriers for people with disabilities again and again. Each budget cut translates into putting one more barrier up, until we find that over a period we are back to where we started from in the late 1970s. The least the government could do is finalise agreements with the states which provide a decent level of funding to the states to ensure that, particularly in the area of accommodation, a decent amount and a decent quality of accommodation could be provided for people with disabilities. These are people who are currently not receiving adequate accommodation support, particularly those families where ageing relativesâpeople over the age of 65âare caring for adult offspring with serious disabilities.

If this government walks awayâas it seems to be planning to doâfrom the multilateral agreement that has up until now existed between the Commonwealth and the states and negotiates a variety of deals with the states, we will effectively have the demolition of another plank in disability reform, the Commonwealth-state disability agreement. If we see the demolition of the Commonwealth-state disability agreement, we will also see the loss of the capacity of the Commonwealth to require each of the states to pass legislation that mirrors the Commonwealth legislation. That will mean that we will no longer have a consistent national rights oriented framework for disability services.

What we face, as a result of this government's budget cuts to those with disabilities and the government's incapacity to negotiate a new agreement with the states over disabilities, is the loss of a national agreement and the loss of any adequate support for people who need decent accommodation. It is a backward step for those who need the government's support and a shameful mark against a government that has shown its true colours in its lack of support for the most disadvantaged in our community: those with severe and profound disabilities.

talk.start.para: âYou are reliable, you have been productive from day one, you make fewer costly mistakes, you are focused on your job and you have the potential to make a business more profitable. You are the dream employee. Yet, every second Wednesday, you line up outside a Centrelink office waiting to hand in your social security form. Day in and day out you apply for jobs that you could do standing on your head. Day in and day out you keep getting knocked back. You soon start to doubt your own ability. You become despondent and bitter. You become trapped in the vicious circle of despair, which further restricts your chances of getting a job.

speech.para: The other night on TV I heard a Welsh coalminer sum up perfectly what I am talking about. He said, `There is nothing so cold, so dark and so black as being unemployed and over 40.' This feeling of total dejection can come whether you are a business executive, a parent returning to the work force or a factory worker. I do not know how many members of this House can relate to this feeling, but I can. I spent 4Â½ years of my life between the ages of 50 and 55 being unemployed. I was a qualified school teacher who was working in the tourist industry when I was retrenched. I learned of my fate on a Wednesday and was told to finish up on Friday. This meant that my whole life changed dramatically. I took it on the chin. I thought I would take some time off, catch up with friends and then I would get another job. I was wrong. It was not as if I wanted a highly paid job or a high-powered job; twenty hours a week being a shop assistant would have done. I needed a job; any jobâone that provided me with some cash flow and a social outlet.

People, particularly some bureaucrats and politicians, do not realise that when a person of mature age loses a job it means that the family struggles to pay the mortgage and the car payments, to keep the children in school and to face all the other bills that are associated with running a household. It is a very hard and devastating time.

Last week while travelling in a cab I started up a conversation with the cab driver. He was saying that Australia has the most educated cab fleet in the world. He himself had two degrees and was a former marketing manager before being retrenched at 55. Because he could not find employment, he gained a cab licence and was driving, but only part time. He said he had applied for hundreds of jobs over the past year and had finally managed to get an interview for a job as a storeman and packer at a sheet metal companyânot his preferred job but a full-time job nonetheless. I wish him all the best.

The over-40s in Australia are the largest demographic group by age, and I caution both sides of the House that if their employment needs are ignored they could develop into a potential political time bomb. It is easier for me to stand here in the House today and say that something must be done because, in Lilley, I am doing something. I have facilitated the formation of a self-help job network that specialises in finding jobs for people over the age of 40. This employment network for over-40s is vital because there are so many talented mature age people in Lilley whose knowledge and abilities are going to waste.

I was very fortunate recently to meet a gentleman by the name of Rod Murray. Rod, like me, knows what it is like to be middle-aged and unemployed. He was 45 years of age with three children when he lost his job. He was forced to sell his house, take his children out of school and move his family to his mother's two-bedroom home in another state. However, Rod is fighting back and is the voluntary chairman of a group called `Don't Overlook Mature-age Expertise in Redlands'âDOMER. The DOMER group consists of over 50 members who actively seek jobs for older people by canvassing businesses for employment opportunities. Everybody in the organisation is required, as part of their membership, to make some effort on behalf of the DOMER group. Once a fortnight they spend half a day on the phones in the office, canvassing businesses for jobs for the groupânot for themselves but for the group.

The figures in Redlands are very promising. On average, after a session on the phones, each DOMER member has contacted at least two willing employers. This equates to about eight jobs a day and about 40 jobs a week. A major spin-off of the network is that it helps rebuild self-esteem. It gives members the chance to unload their frustrations and fears, to receive valuable support and to relate to people who are dealing with similar life experiences.

It was not long before Rod realised that the over-40s job seekers were a very saleable item if marketed effectively. On more than one occasion employers told him, `Thank goodness, we've now got somewhere to go where we can find a mature age person.' The underlying sentiment is that middle aged employees are stable, willing to work five days a week and will do their job from nine until five.

Unemployment data also shows that, while over-40s tend to be unemployed longer than younger people, they are six times less likely to return to the unemployment queues. I quickly realised while listening to Rod that it was time a DOMER-style group was set up in Lilley. I sent out a press release to our local Quest papers, the Northern News and the Northside Chronicle, which read:
Unemployed over 40s are being targeted by the Federal member for Lilley Elizabeth Grace, who wants to set up a self-help organisation to find jobs for older people.
Mrs Grace is joining forces with Rod Murray, who has set up the Don't Overlook Mature-age Expertises Redlands (DOMER) group.
Mrs Grace said she was looking for a positive community response for the formation of a DOMER style branch in Lilley.

And a positive community response is what I got. I was overwhelmed: 15 people contacted my office within two hours of the papers being delivered, and in all we took some 50 phone calls, including two from employers who were willing to employ someone over the age of 40.

A public meeting was organised to discuss the issue and it gave unanimous support for starting a DOMER-style branch in Lilley. It was a great feeling to know that as a community we had come together and were about to achieve something positive. This was because everyone in the room was committed to making the program workânone of them were unemployed intentionally and none of them wanted to remain unemployed.

We named the new group DOMEN (Don't Overlook Mature-age Expertise Northside) and elected Robert Massey of Sandgate as the first chairman, June Fitzgerald of Nudgee as vice-chairman, Loretta Parchimowicz of Nundah as treasurer and Ross Walters of Chermside as secretary, and committee members elected were Barry Gorton of Kalinga, Paul Froggatt of Sandgate and Robert Zorzetto from Boondallâa huge spread across my electorate.

The newly elected president, Robert Massey, sent me some interesting facts about the group. He said, `At the meeting you organised 24 mature aged men and women attended indicating their need for employment. This small pocket collectively offered employers a range of 672 years of experience or in excess of 10Â½ million working hours. The mature aged unemployed represent a vital resource which is currently lost to the Australian work force. Australia simply cannot afford to lose such valuable expertise.'

As a group we have certainly started the ball rolling. We have had the offer of rent-free premises from which to operate, and I would personally like to thank Mr Ian Pritchard from Simplicity Funerals at Kedron for making this possible. A computer is on its way, as well as other general office equipment such as tables, chairs and filing cabinets.

I am in the process of securing some set-up funding from local Rotary clubs to pay for the telephone lines and the cost of incorporating the group. The new group will also have the benefit of a ready-made database thanks to my 1998 edition of the Lilley Business Directory, which contains over 700 local businesses and community organisations employing some 10,000 residents across the electorate.

The aim of my directory is to encourage residents to purchase local goods and services, giving local businesses the incentive to expand and employ more Australians. Hopefully, these will include more mature age Australians. And it is working, because recently I received a letter from local businessman Clem Scanlan, from Clem Scanlan and Associates, who wrote:

We thank you for the support given to small business. We are happy to advise that our practice has improved over the past year and we will soon be in a position to engage the services of another cadet. We welcome the support of the people in government.

The promotion of DOMEN and the benefits of employing someone over the age of 40 will feature in my next electorate-wide business newsletter. This newsletter reaches over 4Â½ thousand Lilley businesses. Furthermore, the DOMEN group will have access to 40 of the top 400 Queensland owned companies that are based in my electorate. The key to the success of the whole program is networking and I am sure DOMEN can forge themselves into an effective self-help employment service. I call on the government to have a long, hard look at this issue and offer some realistic assistance to the jobless mature aged. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI enjoyed listening to the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Elizabeth Grace) speaking in a convincing fashion about the plight of mature aged unemployed people, particularly people over 40. Indeed, she made reference to people over 55. It would be a little more convincing if she were also on record in relation to decision of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) to include superannuation as part of the assets test for those aged over 55. The effect of that decision is to give anyone who turns 55 and happens to be without work some nine months in which to find a job. If they are unable to find a job during that period, they become effectively retired for life because superannuation is included as part of the assets test. They are not eligible for any social security support and therefore they have to dip into their superannuation in order to live. In order to do that, they have to retire. That is a most unfortunate piece of government policy, dating back to 1996. I hope that the member for Lilley and others do everything they can to address it.

speech.para: Just before the House rose last year, back on 5 December in the appropriations debate, I held up a car tidy bag in the House which had been produced by a company which rejoiced in the name of No Worries Pty Ltd and described the product as the `Aussie Care' car tidy bag. It had an `Australian Made' logo on it with the familiar green triangle and the yellow kangaroo silhouetted against it. In case we still had not got the message, it even had the `Keep Australia beautiful' logo on it.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you would have been excused for thinking that this `Aussie Care' car tidy bag from the No Worries company with the `Australian Made' and `Keep Australia beautiful' logos was in fact manufactured in Australia, but you would have been wrong. If you opened up the car tidy bag and looked inside it, it turned out that it was made in India.

That was just one of the unsatisfactory consequences of the Howard Liberal government's decision in August 1996 to withdraw $2 million in funding from the Advance Australia Foundation, which caused that foundation to go into liquidation. At the time I raised this issue back in December, quite appropriately there was some media interest in it. A spokesman for the consumer affairs minister, by way of response to these concerns, said:
. . . the Government withdrew funding from AAF because an independent audit had shown it was a loss-making exercise.
The Government strongly supported the Australian Made campaign, but the AAF had proved it was not the appropriate forum.

The bad news for the minister is that this defence was nonsense. It so incensed Mr James Malone, the former Chief Executive of the Advance Australia Foundation, that he wrote to the minister to set him straight. It is worth quoting from that letter where Mr Malone says:
Briefly the facts are:

. April 1996: I briefed the then Minister for Administrative Services, David Jull, on the AAF's plans to rejuvenate the Australian Made campaign including moving it to a self funding basis over a four year period. The Minister said that the government was unlikely to remove funding from the Australian Made campaign.
. May: The Minister advised that, as an outcome of the government's general cut back in expenditure, contrary to his earlier opinion withdrawal of funding was now likely.

. June: I again visited the Minister and reported that after careful study the Foundation had confirmed it could continue the campaign on a self funding basis provided government support was available during the transitional period on a phasing out basis.

. July 3: My chairman and I met with the Minister and advised that if government was unable to provide a firm undertaking of funding, the board of the AAF was certain to place it in voluntary liquidation.
`Certain'. The letter continues:
The Minister said he could not provide the undertaking and reiterated that funding was highly unlikely.

. July 5: In view of this situation and an independent report which had advised that if the government withdrew funding, the viability of the Foundation was dubious, the board of the Foundation formally decided that the Foundation was unable to maintain its operations on a viable basis. It therefore placed the Foundation in voluntary liquidation and informed the Minister of that action. That outcome was announced in a joint press statement by my chairman and the Minister who congratulated the Foundation on its work with the campaign.

The charge that the Advance Australia Foundation was not the appropriate forum for the Australian Made campaign was entirely without foundation. This body had run the campaign successfully over a period of 12 years. It created between 900 and 2,000 jobs each year, and contributed some $360 million to gross domestic product.

Mr Malone's letter referred the minister also to an economic evaluation carried out in September 1995âpresumably held amongst the records of the former Department of Administrative Servicesâwhich confirms the effectiveness of the campaign under the Advance Australia Foundation's management. Mr Malone's letter concludes:
. . . I ask that you ensure no further statements of the kind quoted above are repeated by your staff.

It is not particularly surprising that Mr Malone had to write to the minister to set him straight. By my recollection, this is the fourth minister in the Howard government to handle this portfolio area in less than two yearsâfollowing ministers Geoff Prosser, David Jull and Senator Ellison who, for various reasons, fell by the wayside. Indeed, I am told by press representatives who have been pursuing this area of sorry inaction by the government that things had `gone a bit slowly' because of the frequent change of minister. In all seriousness, this was advanced as the reason.

But there is another aspect of Mr Malone's letter which is quite disturbing. If you look at the timing of this, you can see that on 3 July the government knew that the Advance Australia Foundation would close; there was a formal announcement by Minister Jull and the foundation's chairman on 10 July; and yet it still continued to collect cheques. For example, from the plastics company Kevron, it collected a cheque sent off on 17 July. Kevron has gone back and sought a refund of this cheque which did not relate to the previous year's liability but related to the forthcoming financial year, and for which they have received no service whatsoeverâno promotion of the logo, no true blue campaign, no policing of the logo.

So we have a situation here where the government was told that the Advance Australia Foundation would go into liquidation, yet it allowed licensees to continue paying. That is an act of considerable deception. It confirms again just what a mess the Buy Australian campaign has become following the election of the Howard government. More than 18 months has passed since the Advance Australia Foundation went into liquidation. There is no sign of the replacement Buy Australian campaign promised by the government. There has been no promotion, no effective policing of the logo. Small businesses around Australia and in the north-west of Melbourne are sick and tired of empty rhetoric surrounding the issue of the Australian Made logo and the promised replacementâa promise made many months ago, still yet to be fulfilled.

We have a government which sees itself as self-titled champions of small business, but which is doing nothing to assist small business. I know, for example, that Mr Chambers from Kevron Plastics is quoted in the Small Business Digest of February 1998 as saying:
I showed the Minister for Small Business the Hon. Peter Reith a sample of the `offending product'â
that is, the made in India Buy Australian productâ
and quite frankly was astounded that he did not seem to care.
Yet we have the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) writing to small businesses in April 1997 saying:
My pledge now is to continue to listen to small business and work in tangible ways to make running a business easier.

Australian Made was never broken; why on earth did this government seek to fix it? The government has to do two things as a matter of urgency: it ought to give back the licence fees paid under false pretences after the Advance Australia Foundation went into voluntary liquidation; and it should restore the Australian Made campaign with a code of practice, promotional support and a protection mechanism so that small business can get on with the job at hand. This is a government that says, `We are the friends of small business.' With friends like these, who needs enemies?

talk.start.para: âToday I would like to refer to some extraordinary Australians and the situation that many of them face and sketch out how I believe we can better honour and support these heroic people. I greatly admire the thousands of Australians who selflessly give of themselves to care for a family member who has a disability. The Howard government's carers package demonstrates the coalition's understanding of the enormous good carers bring to the community. While your unceasing work continues, governments grapple with the challenges that are for you part of your everyday existence. Commonwealth-state disability agreement negotiations lurch along. I hope families of people with disabilities are not too dismayed at the political posturing that surrounds this type of negotiation.

speech.para: The CSDA assigned funding responsibility for employment services to the Commonwealth, relieving the states of the need to continue previous funding in this area. The Commonwealth provides increasing tax sharing funds to the states and territories who are broadly responsible for accommodation and other support services. Since the start of the CSDA to 1997-98, state and territory funding as a percentage of overall government outlays on specific disability services fell by six per cent while the Commonwealth share rose by six per cent.

Thankfully, since 1989-90 the Victorian government has increased funding in real terms by a credible 44 per cent, while the Commonwealth funding to the state has increased by 48 per cent. Commonwealth outlays on its own areas of responsibility have increased by over 180 per cent during this time. While the growth in total Commonwealth outlays has outstripped the increases in state outlays, the states and territories continue to provide around 80 per cent of the total funding. The current negotiations provide for significant real increases in Commonwealth contributions to the states. Growth funds and yearly indexation amounts to an increase of more than $100 million in Commonwealth funding on offer from the original negotiation starting point.

Any suggestion that the federal government intends cutting funds for disability services is simply mischievous nonsense. In addition, the efficiency dividend has been removed. The opportunities for efficiency improvements should not be overlooked, but as a good friend of mine in the sector puts it, `How many wheelchairs can one pair of hands push?' To his credit, Minister Smith has also made it clear that the Commonwealth will sit down with state and territory governments to discuss how unmet demand might be addressed once the second agreement is signed. We simply must get on with it. A cooperative partnership between the states, the Commonwealth and leading disability groups is the desire of the minister.

In the 1950s families of intellectually disabled people and committed individuals set about providing services and facilities to enable disabled people to develop skills, to enjoy life and to fulfil their potential. Their dream is alive today, and families and provider organisations still work towards it. They deserve to know where services are going and to be able to plan with certainty for the future. The states and territories should all sign the second CSDA and join the Commonwealth in the joint task of mapping out how a more effective and coordinated response can be implemented to the unmet demand within the disability sector.

This need to look forward is becoming increasingly crucial. The arguments in favour of more resources are, in some cases, weakened by decisions which fail to maximise the value of resources already available. With limited services, rational choices are producing perverse impacts on the disability sector. Current policies produce confounding signals for families and snuff out hope for the future. The current supply of supported accommodation, respite and day services falls well short of demand.

The work of the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, commissioned as part of the review of the first CSDA, revealed that there are at least 13,400 people with a disability who have some element of unmet accommodation and respite care demand. In the region that includes Dunkley there are some 229 people on waiting lists for CRUs, and I think we have nine places in the pipeline for the foreseeable future. These places are firstly allocated to people at risk, those who are homeless, abused or neglected or likely to be so. While I understand the emphasis given to those at risk, the pitiful number of places coming on stream barely caters for those in this threatening situation.

The priority given to relocating people from closing state-run facilities produces a churning of currently accommodated people into higher standard facilities while those on waiting lists get no closer to a place. Settling for modest, comfortable and dignified facilities while we commit to making inroads into the waiting lists might provide more hope for the families playing the primary carer role. Do these families turn their backs on all they believe in, break their own hearts and pledges to their intellectually disabled family member and abandon their child at the local state department offices just to gain a priority ranking? Where is the encouragement for these families to continue to do what we hope of them while policies reward the opposite behaviour?

Opportunities for voluntary private investment in facilities are quashed by state vacancy management processes. Community and individual fundraising efforts are curtailed by the uncertainty of whom this effort will benefit. Little wonder quality respite care facilities like Connor House are stretched to breaking point, with one day a month support for families being as precious as gold.

The institute's research identified 12,000 people with an unmet demand for day services. Places are snapped up as quickly as they appear, as demonstrated by Southern Autistic's recently opened Beachlynn Services in Seaford. Their experience mirrors the record of long respected and successful local providers like Woorinyan and Kankama. We have no retirement structure within the sector. Notwithstanding the hastened metabolic rates of many people with intellectual disability, we do not provide a supported environment for disabled people to age in comfort.

The notion of ageing in place so valued in the aged care sector does not express itself in disability service policies. Why not? A managed transition of an ageing person with a disability would ensure more appropriate care for the individual and vacancies in employment, respite and support programs for the next generation requiring care. The ageing in place model also provides a possible way for improved efficiencies and value for money. Services could adapt to the changing needs of the client, perhaps at the one integrated venue, providing complementary programs in an environment that is familiar and comforting.

Some might dismiss this idea as too much like an institution but, as those in the sector constantly remind me, there are good and bad institutions. A successful integrated model can only be positive. Such a model would help overcome much of the duplication, competitiveness and bureaucracy of current arrangements. In Victoria two services are being established and a further one planned within 500 metres of one another. All will operate their own transport services, require organisational infrastructure and incur administrative seepage from available funds. Can we afford this type of bureaucracy and fragmentation when such unmet demand exists? Moreover, governments are embracing a network approach to the provision of community health and medical services to maximise the coordination and value for money. Is this the future of disability services?

Networking or greater levels of agency cooperation may also help to reduce the retention of resources within excessively intrusive state bureaucracies who have yet to grant general competency standing to disability service providers. A strengthened purchaser-provider model focused on performance benchmarks and outcomes would relieve the need for state departments to oversee every detail of the provider's activity while also weeding out the non-performers in the sector.

This approach would encourage providers and agencies to work together in contrast to the constrained communication and cooperation that occurs under a direct competitive tendering formula. It would promote a culture of partnership and a more mature working relationship between state departments and community based providers. Services like E.W. Tipping Foundation who appear able to operate accommodation services at a fraction of the cost of facilities that are directly managed by the state could bid for the cost-effective delivery of these services and stand on their record.

Freed of the day-to-day supervision role, state officials could work more closely with families to develop and implement care plans for people with disabilities and ensure that this information is reflected in the planning for future services. The correlation of these needs with an ongoing mapping of services available will provide the building blocks of future service planning. We would have solid information to feed into funding frameworks and forward planning under future Commonwealth-state disability agreements.

The decisions of earlier generations are about to come home with a bang. The policies of deinstitutionalisation, born out of a commitment to independence, dignity and community engagement, will mature into a huge level of unmet demand for services and accommodation that we simply must address. There are about 1,400 intellectually disabled people living with parents who are well into their 60s who have not benefited from the community support their circumstances and commitment have warranted.

The untiring efforts of these families has helped to paper over the shortfall in government services and the failure to adequately resource the shift to care in the community. These people will not be able to continue this work indefinitely. We need to give them the comfort and peace of knowing that proper care is available for their adult children. We need to assure them that ever-selfless, lifelong carers earn a peaceful retirement.

Let us get this second Commonwealth-state disability agreement in place. Let us double our efforts to tackle the current and future challenges facing those committed to a better future for people with intellectual disabilities and their families. I contrast this effort at a constructive, practical and useful contribution to the dribble the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) went on with and say that hers is not the sort of contribution we hope for from those people genuinely interested in this sector if we are going to move this debate forward.

talk.start.para: âIn the grievance debate today I would like to cover a topic that I have mentioned in this House on many occasions but which I think needs to be repeated time and time again. Over the Christmas and New Year break we have seen a great many developments take place concerning plans for the construction of Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek. As was expected, the Howard coalition government, keen to limit public comment and retard the expert examination of its draft environmental impact statement, orchestrated its release just days prior to the Christmas break and allowed only 12 weeksâlater graciously extended to 14 weeksâfor the public to make its submissions on the document.

speech.para: The token two-week extension by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) was hardly enough to make up for the fact that such an important, lengthy and detailed report had been released for public consumption at the beginning of a peak holiday period. If he was as interested in providing a full and transparent EIS process for the people of Sydney as he states, he would have doubled the time for submissions, not just added to it by a meagre two weeks.

The EIS report itself was a sad mixture of deficient analysis and incomplete research. The independent auditor's report on the EIS confirmed it as such just over a month later. It said the EIS was `deficient', `limited' and `ambiguous'. The independent auditor's report is a devastating indictment of the Howard government's claims to be pursuing an EIS on Badgerys Creek that leaves no stone unturned. The report states:

As a result of . . . time and cost constraints imposed by the Department of Transport and Regional Development, the draft EIS generally does not go into the degree of detail that could reasonably be expected for such a major proposal.

The report said the Howard government's EIS had failed to examine the environmental effect of not building a new airport; failed to provide an adequate economic analysis of the development; failed to build community confidence in the EIS; failed to identify how Kingsford Smith and a new airport at Badgerys Creek would operate together; and failed to satisfactorily examine the impact that noise generated by the airport would have on Sydney's population, especially those living in Sydney's west.
The Minister for the Environment has said that the auditor's report contains some important criticisms which the government must respond to. Judging by its form so far, I am not holding my breath.

During the holiday break we were also treated to some refreshing outbreaks of honesty from the government's own ranks. After suffering the rantings of the Member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) last year concerning party loyalty and opposition to Badgerys Creek, I must admit I enjoyed watching his very senior colleague, the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey), come out strongly against the proposed airport's development. With his local member's hat on, the Minister for Finance put out a press release over the break which said, `I remain to be convinced about any of the proposals for Badgerys Creek.' You cannot get much more unambiguous than that. I hope the member for North Sydney uses the opportunity of this first sitting week of parliament to drop into the office of the Minister for Finance and perhaps over a cup of tea quietly tell him that his opposition to Badgerys Creek is inconsistent with the government and his party's line.

The member for North Sydney, the champion of consistency and party unity we know him to be, should do nothing less if he wants to remain faithful to his own stance on this issue. But the former Premier of New South Wales was not the only government member making the member for North Sydney look foolish over the summer break. So too were his fellow classmates of 1996: the member for Macquarie (Mr Bartlett) and the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly).

The member for Macquarie rose in this House for the first time late last year to express his reservations about Badgerys Creek. He said he had been campaigning privately on this issue in his own electorate for some time. I welcome his efforts. The member for Lindsay conducted a newsletter poll of her electorate to find out just how much opposition there was to Badgerys Creek airport. After finding 60 per cent of replies were firmly against its development, the member for Lindsay not only came out against the airport but also advocated the construction of an immense floating international air centre just outside Sydney's headsâa suggestion which surprisingly won her some support from members on her own side.

I will take great pleasure in reminding government members the next time I am ridiculed for supporting an airportâfor example, at Goulburn or Wilton, linked between Sydney and Canberra by a very fast trainâthat within their own ranks they have a few paid up members of the `floating airport brigade'. I think that should shut them up quickly.

Even the member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron)âI am glad he is in the House now; I assume he will also be speaking later in this debateâwas heard to murmur some misgivings about Sydney's west airport, although having seen his own electorate survey, which I believe is heavily biased in favour of the airport, I am not holding my breath as to when we will see an outright condemnation of its construction from him.

Over the break we also witnessed the amazing actions of the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit). As a person who suffered the member for Lowe's vitriol and ridicule for choosing to voice my opposition in this House and other places to Badgerys Creek airport, I was more than surprised when suddenly, just over a month ago, the member for Lowe publicly announced that Badgerys Creek was, in his opinion, no longer a suitable site to build a 24-hour international airport. I certainly welcomed his change of heart, but to watch him then resign from his party only a few weeks later, stating that he was doing so on a matter of political consistency and principle, left me quite incredulous. The member for Lowe is a seriously diminished figure in this House. How any one man can say all the right things about the lack of leadership of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) while discrediting himself at the same time with his own stupefying hypocrisy is beyond me.

The most recent development on Badgerys Creek airport came last Friday when the NSW Local Government Associationâa long time supporter and advocate of the proposed airportâreversed its position and now, quite rightly, has come out in opposition to its construction. We owe our thanks for this welcome change of heart to the overwhelming majority of city councils in western Sydney who make up the anti-Badgerys Creek airport group, the Sydney West Alliance. After a long campaign the alliance was finally successful in acquainting the NSW Local Government Association with the true consequences of building such a monstrosity on the doorstep of 1.5 million Sydneysiders.

The people of western Sydney know how badly they will be affected by a 24-hour international airport at Badgerys Creek and are subsequently putting their weight behind the campaign to have plans for its construction rejected once and for all. The campaign against Badgerys Creek is not the work of ratbag activists or single issue loonies. It is driven by everyday mums and dadsâby apolitical Australian citizens who ordinarily would not know a protest rally from a bar of soap. It is driven by people who want the Howard coalition government not only to listen to their concerns but to act upon them. It ignores their voices at its own peril.

As I have been saying consistently for a great many years, for the sake of 1.4 million western Sydneysiders, it is time we all cut our losses and examined alternative sites for an international airport outside the Sydney basin. They do exist. We should concentrate on suitable sites and real alternatives to Badgerys Creek which we can approach confident in the knowledge that after the necessary environmental tests have been carried out, we can begin construction with as little delay as possible. The people we represent in Sydney's west demand it of us. They demand that we stand in this parliament and every other forum and express their views and their feelings on what they want done about Badgerys Creek airport.

I am pleased that the member for Parramatta has finally decided to do a poll in his electorate and send out a sheet with a for or against whether we should construct Badgerys Creek airport. Surely if the member for Parramatta had listened when he started to doorknock his area before the last election, he would appreciate and understand the concerns of the people he represents. He has not chosen to do so. I have been aware of my constituents' concerns on this issue for the last 10 years, since the decision was first mooted about Badgerys Creek, and I will continue to remain aware. The people I represent demand it of me. The people I represent want me to keep their voice here in this place and I will continue to raise their concerns. I believe that by continuing to do that, we are finally going to get some common sense in this debate.

We finally have members from the coalition government, such as the Minister for Finance, past premier of New South Wales, saying that we must not have an airport at Badgerys Creek. We finally have members of the coalition government leaving their own seats because of certain airport corridors, where the Prime Minister of this country made sure his own electorate was looked after, and to hell with everybody else. They resigned from their government and sit on the opposition benches. The Prime Minister is also coming out and saying that Badgerys Creek is not the ideal spot. Common sense will prevail, and we will not give up. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI listened with interest to the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio), as I always do. I do not doubt that the people of Sydney will give a great deal more weight to her remarks when she is able to stand beside her colleagues the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese), the member for Watson (Mr McLeay) and perhaps the member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton) and sing the same song. At the moment we get Labor singing this completely opportunistic good guy, bad guy routine in which those close to Badgerys decry the airport as a monstrosity whereas those close to Kingsford Smith greet it with open arms as the answer to Sydney's aircraft problem. When the ALP actually gets its act together and can produce a consistent policy across the party as a whole, the people of Sydney will give a great deal more weight to the remarks of the member for Prospect on that subject.

speech.para: I rise tonight not on a subject inviting political opportunism and point scoring and not inviting massive internal consistencies in my own party's position. If we were to ask what is the single greatest failure of public policy across all governments since federationâwhat is that one issue in which we have done the least to serve generations where we have failed in our responsibility as national leadersâyou could argue that that issue would be the relations between indigenous Australians and the rest of the Australian community. Certainly that is a critical issue facing us at the moment. It is the squeaky wheel which is rightly attracting the oil.

In my view, in the long run the critical issue which we have failed to address is something of a sleeper, it is not a particular sexy issue and it does not grab the headlines. It just continues quietly to erode away at the very basis of our quality of life and national ethic. I am talking about the question of how we provide for the retirement of older Australians over generations to come. As I say, Mr Deputy Speaker, there is nothing that grabs you about it instantaneously in the headlines, but I suggest to you that this issue of how we provide for Australians a sustainable retirement income is the most pressing issue of all of the many that we face as a nation.

It was The Who that produced their ode to the beatnik generation in the 1960s with the song My generation in which they sang the famous words `I hope I die before I grow old'. Regrettably, what we are findingâor perhaps not regrettablyâis that we are not dying as a community but living longer than any of those who preceded us. This is creating a challenge for us never before faced by any generation in history. In the post industrial world we have the phenomenon of the advent of retirement. Historically speaking, it is a brand new concept, brand spanking new; it would have been unknown to those of the century which preceded us. But it confronts us in a most arresting way.

In his book, Saving social security's dream, Bill Shipman addressed what he describes as the demographic tidal wave which is confronting the American peopleâthat is, the rapidly ageing population profile of that country and its inability to meet the costs of retirement of Americans. If you project out current expenditures about 10 or 20 years, you will find a nation which is quite literally bankrupt; it will be completely unable to meet the retirement income costs, the federal pensions, of those who will be calling upon them on current trends.

Similarly, in his book, The selfish generation, published just a few months ago, David Thompson looks at the New Zealand situation. Thompson highlights the capricious nature of the outcomes which flow from a lack of planning, a lack of foresight in relation to retirement income provisions. He says:

The prizes and penalties of living in a welfare state are distributed more on the basis of birth date than need, justice or desert. In New Zealand the big winners have been the "welfare generation"âthose born between 1920 and 1945.

What you see happening is an expectation in the community among a particular section born between a particular set of years that the government is going to provide for their retirement when the reality is, for those before them and, I have to confess, as a member of generation X, for those after them, there is really no prospect of government sponsored retirement income at anything like the levels which are currently being provided.

Australia's history in this regard is a sad one. Between 1913 and 1938 there were three separate attempts for Australia to introduce a retirement income scheme, an age pension scheme, that involved a compulsory participation in employment or earnings related retirement income. In 1938, the Lyons UAP government actually passed the enabling legislation, which was called the National Health and Pensions Insurance (Employees' Contributions) Act 1938 and the National Health and Pensions Insurance (Employers' Contributions) Act 1938. The onset of World War II deferred indefinitely the implementation of the scheme. It was not until the early 1970s when Gough Whitlam, I have to confess, initiated the Hancock inquiry into retirement income which subsequently resulted in the implementation of compulsory superannuation, largely under the direction of our colleague Ralph Willis.

I have to say that those successive failures represented one of the greatest omissions of all previous Australian governments. As fond as I am of quoting R.G. Menzies and, in particular, his remark that the art of politics is to persuade people to think in the long run, this is the one critical area in which his government continued to failâto persuade Australians to think in the long run of providing for their own retirement.

I want to look briefly at the three demographic drivers which are the engine behind the crisis we presently face. The first is the declining birth rate. In 1800, the birth rate per 1,000 was 36.6âor 4.3 kids per Australian woman. By 1900, that figure had fallen to 27.2 per 1,000 or 3.5 children. By 1950 it was three children. Today, in 1998, it is 1.8 children.

Next to that declining birth rate you have the phenomenon of increased life expectancyâsomething we all celebrate. In 1800, the life expectancy of the average Australian male was less than 50. By 1900 we had added five years to that life expectancy. By 1950 the figure had risen to an extraordinary 67.1. Today the figure is 75.2 for men and 81.5 for women. One girl in three born in Australia today can expect to live to the age of 100.

That is an extraordinary gift of life given by modern civilisation, but it presents us with this great problem. With a declining birth rate and a rapidly increasing life expectancy, how do we provide for Australians in the later years of their lives, particularly the economically less productive years of their lives when people are not paying taxes?

This is evidenced in the ratio of self-funded to government funded retirees. In 1950, 41.5 per cent were self-funded and 58.5 per cent were government funded. By 1997 that ratio was exactly halved, so you have less than 20 per cent of Australians fully self-funded retirees to over 80 per cent government funded retirees. How do we pay for that explosion in outlays? Primarily, it has been by increasing the proportion of social security expenditure in terms of total Commonwealth outlays. That proportion has more than doubled since 1950â18 per cent at that time to 38.8 per cent today.

So what you see is an absolute explosion of expenditure in meeting the pension costs of this rapidly ageing population. What are we going to do about it? I regard this as the single most pressing problem we face as a nation. Part of the challenge is the fact that it is not a problem that bangs on the door every day. It is not on the front page of the headlines; it is quietly happening behind the scenes. We have to have a sustained determined will of political leadership to do something about it. Generation X is patently being very badly treated by those generations which preceded us. There is currently about $5,000 of Commonwealth debt per head for every Australian born today. That does not include the $40 billion in unfunded Commonwealth superannuation liabilities.

This government is taking the first steps to fund Commonwealth super, but we have to take all of those other steps to really turn the ship around. It has to be turned around or else young Australians will be born into an environment which is completely unsustainable and they will spend the rest of their lives paying off the debts of previous generations. We have to stop the rot, and we have to stop it now. Our government has to be the government which does persuade Australians to take the long-term view.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, tonight I wish to grieve over a number of matters, but I thought you would be particularly interested in a letter I received from a constituent from Berkeley Vale in my electorate. She sent me a letter which I think sums up in simple but very expressive terms the views of many older Australians and how they feel about the current government. The letter is as follows:

speech.para: Dear Michael Lee
Please find encl. our opposition to higher drug charges. Billâ
Bill being her husbandâ
and I are permanently on Zantac. Why does this Government have a `Deathwish' for the sick & elderly?

We are very concerned just what will happen to us all, medication dearer, NO dental help, & food prices rising all the time, & they want a G.S.T., plus NO rise in our Pension. We have to use some of our small savings for the Dentist & any extras we require.
Sincerely hoping matters will change at the next election.
I will not embarrass the woman by naming her.

talk.start.para: âWhich branch is she in?
âThe parliamentary secretary at the table interjects and accuses this lady of being a member of a Labor Party branch. She is not.
âNo, I accused you of getting somebody from the Labor Party to write that.
âThe parliamentary secretary interjects and accuses me of arranging this letter.
âOrder! There is too much conversation across the chamber.

âI can assure the parliamentary secretary that I will write to this constituent and make sure she has a copy of the Hansard so she can read how he has just insulted her and every other older Australian who objects to the changes that this government has been making for older Australians.

speech.para: If the parliamentary secretary thinks that that person has no right to come forward and make a complaint, let me mention to him a second matter which arose during the parliamentary recess. It first came to my attention when two families in my electorateâI state for the benefit of the parliamentary secretary that neither one of them is a member of a branch within my partyâcame to see me to let me know about a change which was to be made to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme that would affect them severely.

They came to see me just before 1 February. They advised me that they had become aware about two days before they saw me that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee had made a decision to take a food supplement called Neocate off the pharmaceutical benefits scheme for infants over the age of two. Both of my constituentsâone from Tumbi Umbi and the other from Killarney Valeâhave boys who are 2Â½ years old. Both of these boys, unfortunately, have a very severe food allergy. One of the sons could eat only Neocate or boiled rice. The specialists for children who suffer these very severe food allergies insist that every now and again their parents take them off Neocate and try them on boiled rice, potato and other simple foods they hope the children will become used to eventually. The parents and the children go through an enormous amount of stress as they try to make sure that the children become eventually able to eat a greater range of foods without having allergic reactions.

These two families in my electorate came to see me because they cannot, on the advice of their specialists, allow their children to eat anything but Neocate and boiled rice. Neocate, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Ms Worth)âI am pleased to say she has entered the chamberâwho is responsible for the pharmaceutical benefits schemeâ

talk.start.para: âWe have fixed it.

âShe interjects and says she has fixed it. I acknowledge the fact that it was her intervention that overcame the problem, but I have a few comments to make about the decision taken that placed these families in this position.

speech.para: Let me begin by explaining to the rest of the House, who probably do not yet know what was involved, that because of a decision taken by PBAC before November Neocate was de-listed for infants over the age of two. That decision was made in November and took effect from 1 February. It meant that for these two families in my electorate, for example, the cost of Neocateâthis is for infants 2Â½ years old who cannot eat anything but Neocate or boiled riceâwas to increase from $3.20 a month to $1,380 a month. Members can understand the distress that this was causing these families in my electorate with such a massive impost being placed on their basic cost of living, not to mention the enormous stress that these two boys' disability was already causing the families.

I understand that only a very small number of children were affected by this decision. I have a few doubts about that, given the fact that two children suffering from this disability are living in my federal electorate. If that were a typical sample, we might expect that several hundred children would be affected nationwide, but I have been told it was a few dozen. I am prepared to accept the figures of the parliamentary secretary and the government.

Even so, it would have to be a very hard-hearted personâI assume it was not the parliamentary secretary nor the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) who made this decision; I assume it was someone within their departmentâwho makesâ

talk.start.para: âHe's going to talk about a mean-spirited government. That's the theme song.
âOrder! I ask the parliamentary secretary to cease interjecting.

âThe member would know about that. It must have been a pretty hard-hearted person who would have made the decision, even if they thought it would affect only 20 families throughout Australia. It would have meant that those 20 families would face an increase of $1,380 in the cost of food which these young children need just to survive. It is pretty hard to believe.

speech.para: When this first came to my attention, we spoke to various people in the department. The best they could tell us was that the decision may be reviewed at a future meeting some time in March. Obviously, we did not hold out very much hope at all that there would be any reconsideration of this decision.

I am pleased to say that as soon as this appeared in one of the major metropolitan dailies, and all the basic television networks developed an immediate interest in this matter, the parliamentary secretary took action to have that decision overturned, which I have already welcomed. It makes me worry that there may be other decisions that are being made by PBAC or other decisions that are not being scrutinised by the parliamentary secretary or the minister. I hope that they have now instituted a change in policies within the department of health to ensure that any decision that could have such a serious effect on individual families requires ministerial approval or at least parliamentary secretary approval.

At the end of the day, people are responsible to the Australian people through this parliament. I hope that bureaucrats are told that decisions of this importance cannot be delegated to them. They should not be delegated to them, unless they are prepared to write minutes to ministers and parliamentary secretaries to ensure that someone who sits in this chamber or the Senate takes responsibility for decisions that can basically cause so much distress and turmoil for individual families. I am sure that, if the parliamentary secretary's approval was needed for that decision, she would never have given approval for that particular decision to go ahead. I hope the minister for health would not have put his name to a minute that recommended families be hit in such a manner.

The two families in my electorate can quite rightly claim credit not only for ensuring that a decision that affected them unfairly was overturned but also for having had this decision overturned, an action which benefits all of the children right around Australia who suffer from this severe food allergy. We can only hope that in time the two boys of the two families that contacted my office overcome their food allergy.

I know there are some suggestions that there are some families who might be using Neocate when it is not absolutely essential. I am sure the government could put in place some form of authority system that ensures doctors are granted permission to prescribe Neocate only when it is essential. But I think the minister understands that the two cases we raised did involve two boys who could eat nothing but Neocate and boiled rice, which is a pretty difficult circumstance for anyone. For those reasons, I wanted to raise that tonight in grievance. I ask that the minister tries to ensure that such an outrage never occurs again.

talk.start.para: âI recognise that we live in an era of economic rationalism. I realise that we must learn to live on a level playing field. I accept that governments must not distort regional economies with the stop-start measures that characterised the previous government. But my grievance today is with the growing perception in some sections of business and the bureaucracy that government should not fund major regional infrastructure projects; I refer particularly to water projects. I do not accept nor have I ever accepted this proposition. While it might be argued that assistance to an individual industry at the expense of another industry can be distortion, that is not the case when 60,000 or more residents require a degree of certainty in the production of a crop which not only sustains the local economy but also provides a substantial contribution to export earning.

speech.para: I repeat the philosophy that I have frequently espoused here and abroad that it is inequitable to ask one group of farmers in one generation growing one particular crop to pay for a major water storage which might conceivably provide subsequent generations of farmers for up to 100 years or more growing totally different crops with certainty in water. I repeat the long held view that major dams should be seen as national assets. It is reasonable to ask farmers to contribute to reticulation and to make a reasonable contribution to the cost of the water, but not to have to cover the full capital cost of the basic head works infrastructure.

Against this background, let me now paint a picture of my district, one of Queensland's leading sugar producing areas. The area has been growing sugar cane for nearly 120 years. It has grappled with issues such as the Kanaka exploitation and it has come through. It learnt 100 years ago that the treatment of fellow human beings in this way was unacceptable and that field work, tough and all as it was, had to pay its way commercially. The era of the cane cutter emerged and this was etched into the Australian psyche. It then survived through two world wars, drought and depression.

In the early 1960s Bundaberg pioneered the cane harvester, and a new era of world leading technology emergedâa technology which is now exported to the world by the largest cane harvester manufacturer, Austoft, based in Bundaberg. The romance is enhanced by the saga of Bundaberg Rum, the great Aussie spirit, which is Bundaberg sugar's leading by-product. It is now Australia's leading spirit label. Then there is an export port with a bulk sugar terminal, a foundry making sugar milling equipment, much of it for export, and there is more. At the growing end of the equation, a Bureau of Sugar Experiment Stations facility leads with world's best practice in the development of new high yield, pest resistant cane varieties. Well you might ask: why this history lesson and why this product profile?

talk.start.para: âIt's a great electorate, that's why.

âNo, it is a bit more than that, Parliamentary Secretary. Let me say to you, to Deputy Speaker Andrews and to all those present tonight that this sugar industry and an emerging fruit and vegetable industry is now at serious risk. I do not want to dramatise it; I just want to spell out the facts. Bundaberg's major water storage is Lake Monduran. It is currently at five per cent of capacity. If you can consider a dam 1.1 times the size of Sydney Harbour that is nearly empty, you get some idea of the gravity of the situation. What this means is that sugar production next season alone will be down 30 per cent.

speech.para: In 1970, after exhaustive studies and a superb information campaign, state and federal authoritiesâand it was not normally federal practice in those days, but they accepted the quality of the schemeâalong with 1,200 farmers funded what was known as the Burnett Kolan scheme, now known as the Bundaberg irrigation scheme. It was premised on two major water storages: one at Lake Monduran, now known as the Fred Haigh Dam, and another one at a place called Kaliwa, on the Burnett River. It has now become an urgent requirement. But yet again you might ask, `Isn't this just another group of farmers that are having a whinge and want a bit more water?' No, it is much more than that. It is the key to the retention of all that infrastructure I have just spoken about and the secondary and tertiary industries that flow from it.

But it goes further than that. This particular sugar industryâjust the Bundaberg-Childers section of it; I am not talking about the whole Queensland coastâcontributes significantly to our export effort. In 1997, four sugar mills at Bundaberg and Childers grew 4,500,0000 tonnes of cane which produced 667,000 tonnes of sugar worth $230 million. Based on 85 per cent of this going to export, the export task alone was $185 million, to say nothing of the domestic effortârum and harvester sales, engineering and the like.

The Bundaberg irrigation scheme was planned on the basis of six megalitres of water per hectare. Revised estimates recommend 7.8 megalitres. However, in 1996 only four megalitres were available. This year just gone, 1997, it was down to 3.4 megalitres. To give you an idea of the gravity of the situation, at this five per cent of dam capacity, only 1.3 megalitres will be available. That will mean a loss of production of 30 per cent. I do not need to tell you how that would affect the district, the City of Bundaberg and the surrounding shires. The effect would be quite profound.

This will impact on the district that now has Australia's worst unemployment, even worse than western Sydney. The Wide Bay-Burnett area now has an unemployment level of 16.6 per cent, so you can imagine the effect that this lack of water is going to have on top of that.

Again you may ask: have these farmers been a bit profligate in the use in their water? Have they just been pouring it on and now we have come to tough times and they are to blame? Again the answer is a firm no. Judicious use of water has been achieved over many years. They have converted, in most instances, to green cane harvesting and trash blanketing, where you cover the ground with a trash blanket to keep the moisture in. There has been water scheduling, the use of scanners and probes, trickle irrigation and best practice flood irrigation. All these things have been done to the point where those measures alone have lifted the production from 8.3 tonnes per megalitre to 11.4 tonnes per megalitre. Those of you who have been associated with the land will know what a good result this is. So it is not as if people want more water just for the sake of it; a huge effort has been made to get world's best practice at the same time. To lift the volume of water from the 4.5 mega litres that were available even in reasonably good times to 7.8 megalitres could bring the yield per hectare to 116 tonnes of cane. This new dam that has been proposed at a site very close to Kaliwa known as Paradiseâ

talk.start.para: âI told you that it was a good electorate.

âYes, it is a good electorate. Come to Paradise. A dam there costing about $150 million would deliver 203,000 megalitres of water. Add that to the existing water and you can see what effect that might have for that district and for Australia. I will not go into too many figures. It will create 2.2 million tonnes of cane on existing land and 2.7 on new landâjust under five million tonnes of extra cane. That translates into 711,000 tonnes of sugar. The return is $250 million, which comes down to about $215 million of exports. Add that to the $185 million I spoke of earlier and you have $400 million coming out of one district. You only have to look at our trade figures released this week to know what a significant contribution that could make.

speech.para: The point I am making is that 60,000 people and a lot of secondary and tertiary industries depend on this crop. There is a desperate need for water. Unemployment is highâthe worst in Australia. I appeal to the federal government, as we emerge from our current deficit problems, to look very seriously at getting back into the business of water storage, not just for the profligate use of water but for areas where industries have demonstrated that they can use this important commodity effectively.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 26 November 1997, on motion by Mr Reith:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThis is really a sad occasion because we have here a second debate on a bill that should never have been introduced. It was a result of a broken election promise by the government. It is unfair. It is a tawdry little political exercise. The sadness is that, if the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] is passed and it achieves the objectives its advocates claim, the benefit to this community will be very low.

speech.para: Most of us think the benefit will be nil, but let us assume that there will be some. What we know is that the net benefit to the community overall economically will be very low, and there is no claim that there will be a social benefit. But even if that claim is incorrect some individualsâsome Australiansâwill lose enormously.

Even if the claims of the advocates are correct about the benefitsâand I will come in a moment to why we think that is extremely dubiousâthere can be no denying that this bill, if it is passed, will mean that some Australians will lose out in one of the most fundamental of ways: they will lose their security in their job. It will take away their rights.

talk.start.para: âIt will not.
âIt will take away their rights, rights you promised they would keep.
âYou know it's not true.

âYou know it is true. The then Leader of the Opposition and now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the then shadow minister who is now the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) both said before the election that, if you are dismissed unfairly, you should have a right of appealâsaid without qualification. They explicitly said, `There will not be such exemptions,' but now they are breaking that promise in a way that is very unfair.

speech.para: Why when the report that triggered this government proposal did not recommend this course of action? A major report into the needs of small business was trumpeted. It recommended some good things, but it did not recommend an unfair dismissal exemption for small business. It said there should be a review of it in about 12 months time, which would be getting on towards now, but it did not recommend an unfair dismissal exemption for small business.

The government got the report, clearly felt that its response did not have much political oomph, so decided it needed to add some. So it delved back into its box of political tricks and said, `This trick worked pretty well in 1995. We had a great campaign about unfair dismissals in 1995. Let's try it again.' Political historyânot just political history but military history and all sorts of historyâis littered with people trying to revisit their former glories: `I had a great victory three years ago. Let's see if we can do it all again when the circumstances are entirely different.' They thought, `We can create another unfair dismissal campaign,' and `I'âthe Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Businessâ`might just, as an aside, advance my leadership aspirations over those of the Treasurer because I can be a hero to the back bench again, leading the assault against unfair dismissals, and perhaps nobody will notice that I promised before the election that we wouldn't do it. Perhaps nobody will notice that the Prime Minister promised before the election that we wouldn't do it.'

That is the genesis of this, but now we have a second stage. We now have this back as one of four potential double dissolution triggers. Why have we got it back in that form? Because the government want to mask their desire to have a double dissolution election about Wik. They want to create three other apparent causes and catalysts of any double dissolution so that they can say, `No, this is not just an election about race; this is an election about these four very fundamental issues,' when we all know, and every Australian who is studying the events knows, that the government is deliberately setting out on a course to have a double dissolution about Wik and this is designed to disguise that stark, unpleasant, unpalatable reality. That is why we are now having this second debate about a bill which should never have been here the first time.

We do not want to have a double dissolution on this bill, for two reasons. Firstly, it gives this mask to the stark reality of the government's plans with regard to Wik and, secondly, there is the too awful to contemplate possibility that if, heaven forbid, this government were re-elected they might be able to pass this bill in its entirety at a joint sitting. The difficulty for us is there is not much room to compromise on this bill: this is something you are for or against. There are not many graduations and there is not much fine print on Wik. There have been lots of amendmentsâa very substantial amount of compromiseâwhich the government have deliberately rejected. Here there is not much room to compromise. You either think that people have a right to an appeal or you do not. You cannot say, `We will give them back half the right,' or, `They will have three-quarters of the right.' They have either got the right to appeal or they have not.

So, notwithstanding that political analysis, notwithstanding that it is arguably perhaps not even in our political interest to do it, we continue to oppose this legislation for one simple reason: it is wrong. This government's legislation says that people can be sacked even if that is harsh, unjust or unreasonable. What this government is saying, and wants us to agree to, is that the objective circumstances can be that your dismissal is harsh, unjust or unreasonable, and we are supposed to say, `But it doesn't matter.' People in Australia today have the right of appeal in those circumstances. Law-abiding, tax paying Australian working people currently have a right of appeal in those circumstances, and the government thinks we might come in here in fear of a double dissolution and say that we agree to taking that right away from them, that they should not have it.

Why have people got that right? We will get trumpeted all this stuff about Labor's unfair dismissal laws and how difficult they were for job creation in small business. I want, if I get time, to say something about the accuracy or otherwise of those reports. But it does not matter if it was true in 1995; we are dealing here with the amendments to the government's laws, to John Howard's law, to Peter Reith's lawâto the law which they said is a fair go all round, that swept away the old laws and put in place a fair go all round. If it was a fair go all round in 1996 when the government passed it, why isn't it a fair go all round now? They stood up and trumpeted that this was a major reform which was fair and balanced in the interests of employers and employees. They said that less than 12 months before they introduced this bill to say, `We thought it was a fair go all round in 1996 but now it is not. It is a fair go part way round. It is a fair go unless you work for small business. It is a fair go unless you happen to be an employee of an enterprise that employs fewer than 15 people.'
