(5) Will the Minister consult Aboriginal organisations to discuss the feasibility of the project.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation is responsible for guiding the reconciliation process. Early in 1998, the Council will adopt a strategic plan for the years 1998 to 2000 which will include activities intended to facilitate and encourage reconciliation between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians leading up to the centenary, when the Council is due to end its work.

The Centenary of Federation Council, which has responsibility for co-ordinating the events to mark the centenary, is within the portfolio of the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts.
As this Council has recently begun its work, it is not yet possible to detail its plans. However, the Council's goal is to ensure events of relevance to all Australians.
The Centenary of Federation Council and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation have made initial contact. The nature and extent of the co-operation is to be discussed and negotiated.
(2) Projects of the sort outlined in this question could be considered for funding under the programs of the Centenary of Federation Council.
(3) The specific provisions of the project outlined in part (2) of the question would determine the answer to this part of the question.

(4) (a) The purpose of the Federation Fund is to finance a number of projects of national significance. The projects are to be well advanced but not necessarily completed by the Centenary of Federation in 2001 and will be selected on the basis that they will generate jobs in the construction phase and make a significant and ongoing contribution to Australia and the Australian economy. Projects will be selected by the Commonwealth Government in consultation with State and Territory Governments.
It is unlikely, however, that the project outlined in part (2) of the question would meet the broad criteria for support from the Federation Fund.

(b) Pilot work for the dole projects were announced by the Hon. Dr David Kemp, Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs on 17 October 1997. The pilot scheme focuses on projects in rural and regional areas. Young job seekers are to participate in community based projects which will enable them to engage with the community, rather than being isolated from it. An important objective of the pilot is to provide communities with quality projects that provide facilities and services which are of value to the community.

As funding has already been announced, the project referred to in this question could not be funded under the pilot work for the dole scheme. However, community groups could submit a proposal for such a project if funding for work for the dole were extended in the future.

(5) The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs would, in the first instance, refer any such project to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) for consideration.

talk.start.para: asked the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

question.para: Is there an international standard for the height which (a) jet and (b) propeller driven aircraft must attain before commencing to turn; if so, (i) what is it and (ii) on how many occasions since 20 March 1996 have planes taking off over the electoral division of Barton commenced to turn at a height which was below the standard.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Details of international standards and recommended practices are contained in the Annexes to the Convention on International Civil Aviation. The Annexes do not stipulate a minimum height that must be reached before an aircraft may commence a turn.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the motion moved by the Member for Cowan on 20 May 1996 relating to the problems associated with the disabling conditions of the Dyslexia and Attention Deficit Disorders.
(2) Has research been undertaken concerning the extent to which those disabilities impede a sufferer's literacy or ability to become fully literate; if so, what are the conclusions of the research.
(3) Will the Government implement the steps proposed in the motion of the Member for Cowan in so far as conditions which may be implicated in illiteracy.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) I am not aware of any detailed research with nationally significant and conclusive findings concerning the extent to which people suffering from Dyslexia and Attention Deficit Disorders are impeded in their literacy development. The Government has decided to commission research under the Literacy Program for schools on the relationship between specific learning disabilities and literacy learning development.

(3) There are no proposals to conduct a parliamentary inquiry into these disorders and their effects. Issues raised in the motion of the Member of Cowan will be among the issues addressed in the proposed research under the Literacy Program.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article by Mr B.A. Santamaria in a recent special edition of News Weekly entitled "How to get Australia working".

(2) Is he able to say whether the primary reason why the Japanese economy is one of the most successful in the world is that their equivalent of the Reserve Bank, the Bank of Japan, creates finance for Japanese manufacturing and rural industries at an interest rate of half of one per cent per annum.
(3) Is he able to say whether the Japanese Ministry of Finance is regenerating Japanese banks by advancing them credit at 0.5%, its companies at 1.6% and running a massive public works program.
(4) Are Singapore and Taiwan successful with interest rates of 3.5% and 5% while the Australian economy, with small business and farm interest rates from 12% to 15%, is largely a failure.
(5) Did the Reserve Bank, until 1984, pay only 1% on Government working balances and advanced money to the Federal Government at 1%, as reported in the Campbell Committee Report.

(6) If so, was the Keating Government's excessive reliance on foreign finance, and its allowance of interest rates to rise above Australia's major Asian trading partners, the major causes of high levels of unemployment, foreign debt, foreign ownership and the rural crisis.

(7) Will the Government legislate to require the Reserve Bank of Australia to finance Australian manufacturing and agricultural industries at an interest rate of less than 2% per annum, particularly in the many industries where Australia has a natural advantage or strategic need.
(8) Will the Government use this strategy to finance resurgence in Australian steel making, and the many steel products; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) My attention has been drawn to the article.

(2) The extremely low level of current interest rates in Japan reflects the present weakness of the Japanese economy; it is not a reason for Japan's past economic success. The cash rate maintained by the Bank of Japan as an instrument of monetary policy is around half a per cent, but the Bank does not lend to manufacturing and rural industries at this rate.

(3) The Japanese Ministry of Finance provides loan funds for various purposes through the Fiscal Investment and Loan Program. These funds come primarily from the postal savings and compulsory employee pensions schemes and are lent at rates currently comparable to those available from commercial lenders. Spending on public works by the Japanese Government has been at high levels over recent years but is being reduced as part of the Government's medium-term fiscal consolidation program.

(4) The 3.5 per cent interest rate for Singapore is a money market rate. The corresponding rate in Taiwan has recently risen to around 8 per cent, while the comparable rate in Australia is 5 per cent.

(5) Until 1983, the Reserve Bank occasionally provided funding to the Commonwealth Government at 1 per cent per annum by buying Treasury bills from the Commonwealth Government. This facility was used to cover shortfalls in the issue of debt securities by the Commonwealth Government to the private sector. The facility was formally put aside in 1986. Since 1985, market-related interest rates have applied to both cash balances held by the Commonwealth Government at the Reserve Bank and, on the rare occasions when required, overdraft finance provided by the Reserve Bank to the Commonwealth Government.

(6) The levels of unemployment, foreign debt and foreign ownership at any time, together with conditions in rural industries, reflect a variety of factors. The deterioration in Australia's external situation over the past 2 decades reflects both investment and saving deficiencies, with the latter being the more important influence. The decline in national saving has in turn largely reflected a structural deterioration in public saving. The Government's medium term fiscal strategy of achieving underlying budget balance, on average, over the course of the cycle, is intended to address this situation by ensuring that the Government will not, on average, be calling on private saving to fund its investment needs.

(7) and (8) No. The selective provision of finance at below-market interest rates would distort business investment decisions, advantaging some industries at the expense of others. Investment funds are likely to be used most productively when investment decisions are made on a fully commercial basis, with government interventions limited to clear cases of market failure where the benefits of intervention exceed its cost.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 28 August 1997:

question.para: Are foreign carriers flying multiple domestic legs in Australia; if so, (a) to what extent and (b) what procedures are required to enable foreign carriers to fly multiple domestic legs.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Whilst most foreign carriers are permitted to operate to a number of ports within Australia, they are only permitted to carry traffic that is part of an international service between these ports.

(a) There are currently nine foreign scheduled passenger airlines operating multiple domestic legs in Australia. These carriers have the right to carry own stopover traffic and are serving more than two domestic points as part of a round trip, or serve more than two points in Australia on separate flights. Services by British Airways, Malaysian Airlines, Thai Airways International, Korean Air, EVA Airways, Asiana Airlines, Mandarin Airlines, Air Niugini and South African Airways fall into this category.

(b) Own stopover rights, many of which were introduced since 1992 as a consequence of Australia's overall program of bilateral air services negotiations, have been agreed progressively as international air services have been liberalised. These rights would have been exchanged for appropriate benefits such as access to beyond points for Australian carriers or for benefits for Australian industries such as tourism.

There are also arrangements which have existed for many years to allow case-by-case approvals for international carriers to assist with the ad hoc or emergency movement of domestic cargo or passengers (for example, in cases where passengers might otherwise be stranded) where Australian carriers are not able to do so.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 August 1997:

question.para: (1) How many staff are in each battalion in the Australian Army.

(2) How many staff are in each vessel of the (a) DDG, (b) FFG, (c) FFH, (d) DE, (e) Patrol Boat, (f) Submarine, (g) Afloat Support, (h) Mine Countermeasures, (i) Amphibious and (j) Marine Science RAN Combat Force Element Groups.
(3) How many staff are in each RAAF squadron.
(4) What is the peacetime establishment and number of staff of 7 Task Force at 27 August 1997.
(5) Is 7 Task Force fully resourced; if not, what resources are still to be provided.
(6) Will 7 Task Force reach its peacetime establishment and be fully resourced; if so, when.

talk.start.para: âIn my answer to part (2) of question No. 2169 (Hansard , 20 October 1997, page 9328) incorrect figures were provided for the number of personnel onboard the Collins and the Oberon Class submarines. The correct figures are:

answer.para: Submarine (Collins)â42; Submarine (Oberon)â65.

The error occurred because the Scheme of Complement for major fleet units varies depending on the type of operations being conducted. In this case, additional personnel present onboard the Collins and Oberon submarines at the time of the original answer's collation were incorrectly included in the figure for the Standard Scheme of Complement.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 August 1997:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to recent media reports alleging a reduction in competition in the funeral industry as a result of business takeovers and mergers.
(2) If so, will the Government ensure that competition remains in the funeral industry and that consumers are not exploited at a vulnerable time in their lives.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The ACCC has general responsibilities to administer Australia's competition laws and has been closely monitoring competition in the funeral industry over recent years.

The ACCC completed a major investigation into the acquisitions of funeral interests by Service Corporation International Australia Pty Ltd (SCIA) and Funeral Services Australasia Pty Ltd (FSA) in October 1996. The ACCC did not oppose these acquisitions because it did not consider them to be in breach of section 50 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 (TPA).

The ACCC has continued to monitor the funeral industry since October 1996. Both SCIA and FSA advise the ACCC of any acquisitions which they are proposing to make so the ACCC may assess the effect of the proposed acquisition on competition and, in an appropriate case, conduct market enquiries. Major considerations for the ACCC in conducting such assessments are the effect of such acquisitions in the relevant markets and the vertical integration issues which may arise from an acquisition, such as the ownership of crematoria or cemeteries.

The Government and the ACCC are aware of recent media reports alleging a reduction in competition in the funeral industry. Thus far the ACCC has concluded that subsequent acquisitions in the industry have not led to a substantial lessening of competition in a market in terms of section 50 of the TPA. However, the ACCC will continue to monitor the level of competition in the funeral industry.

The ACCC's investigations revealed that there is not a great deal of price competition in the funeral industry. Whilst some discount funeral operations have had some success, consumers generally do not seek to compare prices between competing funeral service providers. Rather, funeral services are selected on the basis of previous dealing or on the recommendation of family or friends.

The Government and the ACCC are aware of the potential for consumers to be exploited in relation to the provision of funeral services, particularly in relation to prepaid funeral services. There is anecdotal evidence of funeral services providers using high pressure sales tactics to attempt to convince elderly people to acquire prepaid funeral services. In an appropriate case the ACCC would be seeking to take enforcement action under the unconscionable conduct provisions of the TPA in relation to such conduct.
State and Territory Legislative Reviews

In accordance with the Competition Principles Agreement 1995 (CPA), the State and Territory governments will, by the year 2000, conduct their own reviews and, where appropriate, reform any of their legislation which may restrict competition in the funeral services industry.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Mr Thomson wrote to the Treasurer on 9 October 1997 advising that the information in his question was partially incorrect. Mr Thomson indicated that AIDC owns a 1.5 per cent stake in Optus, but manages a further 7 per cent on behalf of other investors.
The Government announced the sale of AIDC Ltd to Babcock and Brown and Union Bank of Switzerland in September 1997.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Was the Meridian Investment Trust permitted to preserve in excess of $400 million in trust losses; if so, why.
(2) Has the Government weakened its position on trafficking in trust losses.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Government does not comment on the affairs of individual taxpayers.

(2) The Government has maintained its commitment to the trust loss measures. Legislation to restrict the use of trust losses was introduced into the Parliament on 1 October 1997. This legislation implements the trust loss measures as announced by the former Government in the 1995-96 Budget and modified by announcements in the 1996-97 and 1997-98 Budgets. The legislation contains modifications in response to legitimate issues raised during public consultation on the Exposure Draft legislation on the trust loss measures that was released in February 1997.

subdebateinfo.title: Pricing Developments in Financial Sector: Monitoring
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2218)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Does the Government informally monitor pricing developments in the financial sector; if so, (a) how, (b) who is responsible for the monitoring, (c) how many persons assist in the process, (d) from which offices or Departments are they drawn and (e) do they report to him or through an intermediary.
(2) How will the Government oppose unfair or anti-competitive practices in the banking sector.
(3) How long would it take for an action initiated by him against banks for unfair or anti-competitive practices to succeed.
(4) On how many occasions since 2 March 1996 has he initiated action against banks for unfair or anti-competitive practices and what have been the results of the actions.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) conducts informal monitoring of bank fees and charges. The ACCC's informal monitoring program comprises the collection of information from banks on changes to fee structures on transaction accounts as they occur or are planned to occur. This information is tabulated and used to determine whether there are significant changes or trends which suggest the possible need for further investigation. The ACCC has maintained this program since the public inquiry into bank fees and charges by the former Prices Surveillance Authority in 1995.

The Reserve Bank of Australia collects and publishes interest rate data and monitors credit risk standards in the banking sector. The Treasury also keeps a watching brief on bank fees and charges and interest rates, using various published sources, and provides advice to me on developments from time to time.

(2) The ACCC is responsible for investigating any unfair or anti-competitive practices in the banking sector which may be in breach of the Trade Practices Act. There are a number of strategies to ensure compliance with the Act. The ACCC may pursue breaches by taking legal action or settling matters directly with the business in question.

In determining what action to undertake, the ACCC takes into account both the interests of the community generally and those directly affected by anti-competitive or unfair business conduct. Its main goal is to seek compliance with the Act.

In cases where the conduct is blatant and the consequences widespread, it will continue to be appropriate to pursue matters through the courts to seek penalties and/or redress. In other matters, the better course of action will be to seek tangible benefits via enforceable administrative settlements under s.87B of the Act, such as corrective advertising or financial compensation. The ACCC does not require any formal reference from the Government to investigate any sector.

(3) The time taken by the ACCC to pursue an action initiated against banks will depend on many factors, including the nature and complexity of the matter, and the degree of cooperation from the bank(s) concerned. Many matters can be resolved by the ACCC directly with the business concerned, and therefore within a relatively short time-frame.

(4) The ACCC has investigated the practices of the banks several times since 2 March 1996. No evidence of any breach was found. For example, the ACCC was concerned about the possibility of collusive behaviour, based on the size and timing of reductions in housing loan interest rates, when the four major banks simultaneously announced identical decreases in rates.
After investigation, the ACCC was satisfied that no breach of the Act had occurred but has warned the banks that it will continue to monitor their practices.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to concerns expressed by hearing implant manufacturer Cochlear Pty Ltd that Federal Government cuts to research and development concessions have contributed to a 0.5% fall in profits.
(2) Has his Department undertaken research to examine the likely impact on company profits of reduced government research and development concessions.
(3) Has the Australian Taxation Office undertaken an analysis of the likely impact on company profits in Australia in 1997-98 of reduced government research and development concessions.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. However, prior to the 1996-97 Budget the Government did receive representations from Cochlear Pty Ltd concerning the Research and Development (R&D) tax concession. I also note a report of 22 October 1997 in the Australian Financial Review indicating that Cochlear Pty Ltd expects a stronger year and that its "results for the first quarter of the current year are in line with its targeted growth projections".

(2) and (3) Company profits are affected by a number of factors and it is difficult to separate out the impact of any one single factor (such as the availability of a particular tax concession). In this regard, neither Treasury nor the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) have undertaken research examining the impact on company profits of reduced government R&D tax concessions.

However, the December 1996 joint Treasury/ATO/DIST submission to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee dealing with R&D matters examined the impact of reducing the R&D tax concession. Based on BIE analysis the submission argued that the rate of return to the economy from the R&D tax concession at 125 per cent is unequivocally higher than the rate of return from the concession at 150 per cent. That is, at 125 per cent the net benefits to society of the concession are greater than at 150 per cent.

While changes to tax concessions may impact on individual companies, sound economic fundamentals make an important contribution to corporate profitability. For example, the Government has made significant progress towards returning the budget to surplus and this has helped take pressure off interest rates since July 1996 officially-targeted interest rates have been reduced five times, representing a cumulative reduction of 2Â½ percentage points.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Have officers of his Department been assigned to the Prime Minister's task force on tax; if so, how many.
(2) Are members of his personal staff on the task force; if so, how many.
(3) Will the task force incur additional expenditure of departmental funds on consultancies or new staff; if so, what sums.
(4) How many times has the task force met since its formation.
(5) When will the work of the task force be completed.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) One officer from the Treasury and another from the Australian Taxation Office has been assigned to the task force. In addition, officers from within the Treasury and the ATO will be drawn on to support the work of the task force as necessary.
(2) Yes; two.
(3) Funding arrangements for the task force are set out in the Mid Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook released in December 1997.
(4) The task force has met on numerous occasions, the particular number of meetings is the business of the Government not the Opposition.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1997:

question.para: Is the current proportion of Reserve Bank reserves held in gold adequate.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Reserve Bank's media release that accompanied the announcement of the sale of gold reserves on 3 July 1997 said, in part,

`The Australian sales program followed a review by the Bank of the costs and benefits of holding a significant part of international reserves in the form of gold. Following the review, the Bank's Board concluded that, while there was a case to hold some gold as a contingency against unforeseen events, the previous holdings (which amounted to about 20 per cent of international reserves) were no longer justified.'

After making the adjustment to its holdings, the bank holds about 80 tonnes of gold, which represents about 7 per cent of reserves. The Bank believes this is consistent with Australia's long term requirements, and has no plans for additional sales or purchases.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Did the Reserve Bank in its 1996-97 report caution banks against a lowering of lending standards; if so, what measures will he take to ensure that banks operating in Australia manage their lending practices prudently.

answer.para: (1) The 1996-97 Annual Report of the Reserve Bank is available from the Tables Office and I urge the honourable member to check for himself what is in the Report.

The Reserve Bank's general philosophy continues to be that the primary responsibility for the sound operation of a bank lies with its own management and board. However, the Bank has devoted considerable effort to encouraging banks to develop effective risk management systems.

(2) In my press release of 2 September 1997 on the Australian Financial System Reform and in my Ministerial Statement to the Parliament on the same day, I outlined the Government's response to the Final Report of the Financial System Inquiry.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 24 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 99 (Hansard , 20 August 1996, page 3289), have air safety incidents occurred or been reported at or over Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport between 3 May 1996 and 30 June 1997; if so, what.

subdebateinfo.title: Federal Financial Assistance Grants: Funding Cuts
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2257)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 24 September 1997:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No. 652 (Hansard , 4 February 1997, page 99) concerning breaches of safety procedures or near collisions at airport runway intersections at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and other airports throughout Australia, will he update his answer for the period 10 September 1996 to 30 June 1997.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: During the period 10 September 1996 to 30 June 1997 a total of two (2) occurrences were reported to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) involving a breach of safety procedures at runway intersections at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. During that same period, the number of reported occurrences involving a breach of safety procedures at runway intersections at other airports throughout Australia were as follows: one (1) at Mackay Airport; two (2) at Perth Airport; and one (1) at Rockhampton Airport.
A synopsis of each of these occurrences is set out below.
Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
(a) Two fire tenders responding to a fire call, crossed the active runway without a clearance while a British Aerospace BA31 aircraft was on its take off roll.

(b) A Boeing 747 aircraft landed on runway 16R and vacated via the rapid exit taxiway A3. The aircraft was instructed to cross runway 07 then turn left onto taxiway Golf. The instruction was correctly read back. However, the aircraft was subsequently observed to turn left and enter runway 07. This runway was not active and there was no confliction with other traffic.
Mackay Airport

(c) The pilot of a Piper PA-28R-200 aircraft was instructed to contact Mackay Tower at Playstowe for an inbound clearance. The pilot subsequently requested a landing clearance while 3 miles from the runway and on descent to 1,000 ft. After landing on runway 05, the pilot entered runway 14 without obtaining a clearance.
Perth Airport

(d) A Beech 200 aircraft had completed two touch- and- go landings on runway 03 before the pilot made a full stop landing on runway 11. The landing roll was completed east of runway 03. The pilot was cleared to backtrack on runway 11 and hold short of runway 03.
A Boeing 747 aircraft had been cleared for take off when the Beech aircraft was observed by the tower controller to cross the upwind threshold of runway 03.

The Beech 200 cleared the runway 03 flight strip as the Boeing 747 was approximately 1,000 metres into the take-off roll. The controller assessed there was no risk of a collision and the Boeing 747 was allowed to continue its take off roll.

(e) A Boeing 767 landed on runway 21 as a Boeing 737 was on final approach for landing on runway 24. Visibility from the tower was poor due to low cloud. The Boeing 767 vacated runway 21 and the crew were instructed to hold short of runway 24. However, the crew were unable to comply as the aircraft was already 2 to 3 metres into the runway 24 flight strip. The pilot of the Boeing 737 was instructed to go around.
Rockhampton Airport

(f) A Beech 58, VH-WLC had been cleared to backtrack after landing on runway 15. Another Beech 58, VH-WIM had been cleared to land on runway 22. The aerodrome controller then attempted to confirm with the pilot of VH-WLC that he was holding short of runway 22 as he had not been cleared to cross that runway. This transmission and following transmissions were not answered and VH-WLC crossed the runway without a clearance. The pilot of VH-WIM said he had the other traffic sighted and would accept late landing clearance and he subsequently landed without further incident.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 25 September 1997:

question.para: (1) What progress has been made on those Commonwealth properties listed for sale in the (a) 1996-97 and (b) 1997-98 Budgets.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to a press release stating that sales for short term gain will ultimately result in a huge financial loss for the Commonwealth; if so, is this correct.
(3) Which Commonwealth properties in Queensland have been identified for sale as part of the 1997-98 Budget.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The sale of those properties listed for sale in the 1996/97 Budget is nearing a successful completion.

Nine of the 11 properties identified have been sold for total proceeds in excess of $80 million. The remaining 2 properties which were withdrawn from the 96/97 sales program planning and works issues, will be sold in the current financial year.

(b) 57 buildings were identified for sale in the 1997-98 Budget, of which 14 major buildings were to be sold in six packages over two financial years, with the remaining 43 to be marketed over three financial years.
The 10 major buildings packaged for sale in the 97/98 year are currently being marketed, with strong investor and institutional interest being evident.

(2) I am aware of a media release by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator John Faulkner dated 20 August 1997, in which he claims the Government's property sales are for "a short term gain for a long term loss". I assume this is the release to which you refer.
The claims made by Senator Faulkner are incorrect for a number of reasons:
(i) When Senator Faulkner was provided with the table upon which he based his claims, he was clearly advised that it did not specifically cover the 57 properties subsequently selected for sale.

(ii) Senator Faulkner was also advised that a more detailed building-by-building analysis had subsequently been undertaken on the 57 properties as required by the Commonwealth Property Principles. This analysis included a detailed review of each building's prospective financial return having regard to the tenancy outlook, future refurbishment requirements, the cost of capital and other factors.
(iii) Senator Faulkner ignores future benefits that will accrue to the Commonwealth in terms of enhanced flexibility in being able to better tailor accommodation to meet agency requirements.

Additionally, the sale of the 57 properties will enable the Government to release nearly $900 million for other more socially important budgetary purposes, while at the same time allowing the government to address the legacy of neglect left by the previous administration and ensure that many staff are not forced to work in sub-standard or unhealthy workplaces.
(3) The following properties were identified for sale in Queensland in the 1997/98 Budget:

Australian Government Centre, Brisbane; Commonwealth Centre, Rockhampton; Commonwealth Centre, Mackay; Commonwealth Centre, Inala; Commonwealth Offices, Bundaberg; West End Offices, Brisbane; Stanley Place, Townsville; Commonwealth Offices, Woodridge.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Is assistance under the Government's Family Tax Initiative only available for families with dependent children up the age of 18.

(2) Is it a fact that, for the purposes of assessing applicants for Austudy assistance, students are con sidered dependent upon their parents until they reach the age of 25 or satisfy other independence criteria.

(3) If so, why does the Government, for the purposes of assessment under the Family Tax Initiative treat students older than 18 as independent, but for the purposes of assessment for Austudy assistance considers all students dependent upon their parents until they turn 25 or satisfy other independence criteria.
(4) Is the differential treatment fair; if so, why.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes, provided certain conditions are met, including that a dependent child 16 years or older is in full time secondary education.
(2) Yes.

(3) The Family Tax Initiative provides assistance to eligible families with dependent children up to the age of 16âwhether or not receiving full-time educationâand full time secondary students up to the age of 18. This measure recognises the cost of bringing up children and the income foregone when one parent is at home caring for young children.
The age cut-offs for dependent children and secondary students for the purposes of the Family Tax Initiative are consistent with those for Family Payment eligibility.

However, AUSTUDY is directed at both secondary and tertiary students. From the 1996 calendar year, the age at which students are assessed as independent of parental means increased from 22 to 25. This change takes account of the responsibility of parents in meeting the education costs of their children in these circumstances, and ensures that AUSTUDY is better targeted to disadvantaged families keeping their children in education.
(4) The differences in the age cut offs for `child' and `student' in the Family Tax Initiative and AUSTUDY measures reflect the differing target groups, as outlined above.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 September 1997:

question.para: What are the implications for the Australian economy of the balance of trade figures for August 1997 which were announced on 29 September 1997.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The August 1997 International Trade in Goods and Services data reported a trade surplus for the fifth consecutive month. The surplus of $318 million (sa) is $137 million higher than the July result.

Exports of goods and services grew by 4.1 per cent in August, offsetting a 2.6 per cent rise in imports. Non-rural exports grew strongly, particularly gold, transport equipment, metal ores and minerals. Rural exports rose, with strong cereals exports offsetting falls in wool and `other' rural exports. The growth in imports was due to a pick-up in all categories.

The balance on goods and services on average over the year to August 1997, excluding the abnormal effect of RBA official gold sales, is the highest surplus over the equivalent timeframe since the year to August 1991.

The ITGS data provide only a partial picture of Australia's external accounts position and a more complete picture will be available following the release of the ABS September quarter Balance of Payments figures in December.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, 29 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Does the Civil Aviation Safety Authority have power to vary regulations without notification of the variations; if so, how many variations of the aviation regulations are in force which have not been published in the Commonwealth Gazette.
(2) How many variations have been granted, varied, or withdrawn in each 3 month period since 1 January 1994.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has no power to vary regulations. The Civil Aviation Regulations may only be varied by an appropriate legislative amendment. Such amendments are made by the Governor-General in Council and are notified in the Commonwealth Gazette.
(2) On the basis of the answer to part 1, part 2 of the question is not applicable to CASA.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 29 September 1997:

question.para: Has the third position on the National Crime Authority (NCA) remained vacant since Ms B King, QC, resigned; if so, (a) why and (b) has the operational role of the NCA and its capacity to hold hearings been impaired.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: Yes.

(a) A Member of the National Crime Authority must be a person with the personal and professional ability to fulfil a variety of executive and legal functions including presiding at hearings held for the purposes of a special investigation. This requirement necessarily restricts the field and available persons from which an appointment can be made.

(b) Without its normal complement of Members the operational capacity of the NCA, and its capacity to hold hearings, is necessarily below what it would normally be. However, there has been an active search for a new Member, and the Government is currently in the final stages of making an appointment. An announcement is expected soon.

subdebateinfo.title: Proposed Badgerys Creek Airport: Air Quality
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2299)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 30 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Does his Department monitor 6 matters in determining air quality; if so, what are they.
(2) Did the environmental impact statement (EIS) into the proposed Badgerys Creek airport take account of the 6 matters referred to in part(1); if so, what was the outcome; if not, why not.
(3) Did the EIS take into account the US standard of 2.5 microns for fine particles that lodge permanently in the lungs; if so, what was the outcome; if not, why not.
(4) Did the EIS take into account the proposed Australian standard of 10 microns; if so, what was the outcome; if not, why not.

(5) Did the EIS and the summary released to the public take into account the NSW Government urban bushland biodiversity study; if so, does the study confirm pockets of the Cumberland Plain Woodland on the airport site.
(6) Is he able to say whether the Cumberland Plain Woodland has been listed under the Threatened Species Conservation Act (NSW).
(7) Do other plant species considered to be vulnerable lie in the path of the proposed airport; if so, what are they.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. The monitoring of air quality in the Sydney region is a matter for the New South Wales Environment Protection Authority.

(2), (3) and (4) When the Draft EIS is released to the public, the full results of the air quality study will be made available. Pages 33 and 34 of the EIS Summary briefly outline the potential impacts of an airport on air quality, including an assessment of various air toxics and particulate matter.
(5) A detailed study of flora was undertaken for the Draft EIS and the results will be available when the Draft EIS is released publicly. A number of potentially endangered species were identified.
