talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 30 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Did Australia withdraw from the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation (UNIDO); if so, (a) when and (b) was the decision to withdraw from UNIDO made (i) for budgetary reasons, (ii) as a result of Australia's dissatisfaction with the activities or administration of UNIDO or (iii) for some other reason; if so what.
(2) Did he receive a report of a review of multilateral organisations prior to deciding to withdraw from UNIDO; if so, when was the report received.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to an announcement by the United Kingdom that it has reversed its intention to withdraw from UNIDO; if so, is he able to say what were the reasons for the United Kingdom changing its intention.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Australia has announced its intention to withdraw from UNIDO.
(a) Formal notice of intention to withdraw from UNIDO was given on 23 December 1996. The withdrawal will take effect on 1 January 1998.

(b) (i), (ii) and (iii) The primary reasons for the decision are that in an international environment of increased competition for multilateral resources, it is not appropriate to maintain an annual obligatory financial commitment to UNIDO. Funding of each international development agency needs to be based on convergence of the organisation's programs with Australian aid priorities together with the level of agency performance. The Australian Government has determined that Australia's limited aid resources are better focused on higher priority UN development organisations including UNICEF and UNDP.

Support for industrial development in developing countries is more effectively provided through bilateral aid programs and other multilateral institutions than by UNIDO. In particular, the Government considers that direct technical assistance for specific industries and firms is rarely an appropriate use of aid funds, yet this continues to represent a substantial part of UNIDO's work.
(2) I received the section of the review of Australia's involvement in the United Nations, Specialised agencies and the Commonwealth relating to UNIDO on 13 November 1996.

(3) I am aware that the incoming United Kingdom Government announced that it will not proceed with the withdrawal from UNIDO which had been foreshadowed by the previous United Kingdom Government. It is not appropriate for me to comment on the reasons behind changes in other governments' policy positions. The Australian Government came to its own conclusions on the basis of its own analysis and that decision was not affected by decisions made elsewhere.

subdebateinfo.title: Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils: Cost Complaints
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2306)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Has he received complaints from the Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils Ltd concerning the costs imposed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) on local government and other community groups for the provision of statistical material from the 1996 Census.
(2)Will the Government ease the costs burdens on local government associations and community groups when seeking statistical data which is only available through the ABS.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Treasurer respects the confidence of all individuals and organisations who correspond with him.
(2) The ABS applies a pricing policy that essentially seeks to recover the costs of production and distribution of its products and services. This policy is applied even-handedly.

To ensure open access to official statistics, the ABS distributes free copies of its publications containing the main findings of statistical collections free of charge to the media and to public libraries throughout Australia.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Will Australia's banking system perform more efficiently with fewer banks.
(2) When will he announce new appointments to the board of the Reserve Bank of Australia.
(4) In the event of a new Governor of the Reserve Bank being appointed before 2003, will he require the appointee to sign a new statement on the conduct of monetary policy.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Final Report of the Financial System Inquiry stated that there is scope for the banking industry to become more efficient. Encouraging competition in the market is the primary method for increasing the efficiency of the system. Whether that ultimately leads to more or fewer banks cannot be pre-determined.
(2) I expect to announce appointments to the Reserve Bank Board in the near future.
(3) The particular obligations to be met by any new Governor of the Reserve Bank in the future will be determined at the appropriate time.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 1 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to community and business sector reaction, especially small business, to the Government's announcement on 30 September 1997 of its formal response to the fair trading inquiry.

(2) What steps announced by the Government on, 30 September 1997, will assist small business in their dealings with larger businesses, and what benefits will flow to small business as a result of the Government response.
(3) What are the implications of the Government's response for small business development and economic growth in Australia.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The Member's attention is drawn to the answers given to the House of Representatives on 1 October 1997 and 2 October 1997, wherein I cited a wide range of industry reaction to the New Deal: Fair Deal package, which has been resoundingly endorsed by the small business sector.

(2) All of the initiatives announced by the Government in the New Deal: Fair Deal package will assist small business in their dealings with larger business. The benefits which will flow to small business and the community are those outlined in the package, including a more robust, confident and well equipped small business sector to deal with fair trading issues as they arise in commercial activity. I invite the member to examine the content of that package.

(3) The implications of the Government's response for the small business sector are set out in the New Deal: Fair Deal package and have been referred to, in part, in the answer to question 2 above. I invite the member to examine the content of the package.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 1 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Has he indicated to potential purchasers of Essendon Airport that they will not be permitted to redevelop the site for residential purposes.
(2) If so, what legal instrument will prevent the purchaser of Essendon Airport from redeveloping the site for residential purposes.
(3) Will he rule out residential redevelopment of the airport site or any part of it under any circumstances.
(4) What development will he permit at Essendon Airport under private ownership and has he advised potential purchasers of the possibilities.
(5) Will he permit (a) a 24 hour a day amusement park or (b) sporting facilities to be developed at the site.

(6) Did officials from his Department state at a Senate Estimates Committee hearing on 20 August 1997 that covenants requiring continued operation of the site as an airport could be removed with the joint consent of the Federal and Victorian Governments; if so, how does this reconcile with his reported comments referred to in part (1).

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes; Essendon Airport is being offered for sale on a long-term leasehold basis as an airport. The Department of Transport and Regional Development has advised bidders that subleases for residential purposes are not permitted.

(2) Section 34(1) of the Airports Act 1996 provides that Regulations may prohibit specified kinds of subleases of an airport lease. Subleases for residential purposes are specifically prohibited under Regulation 2.04(2)(b) of the Airports Regulations.
(3) See above.
(4) Developments that are appropriate to its role as an airport and its location within the surrounding community will be permitted.

(5) The Airports Act 1996 requires airport master plans and major development plans to be developed and submitted for ministerial approval. Master Plans for leased Federal Airports will go through a public consultation process, before being considered at Ministerial level. Before approving a master plan, the Minister must:
. ensure it meets the overall aviation operational requirements;
. consider the effect it would have on the use of land within and around the airport; and
. consider the consultations undertaken in preparing the plan.
Any proposed major development will go through this process.
(6) Yes. However, this was in the event that the Airport was sold freehold. The Government is now offering Essendon Airport leasehold under the Airports Act 1996.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs at the launch of a book entitled Opportunity Knocks , advising that $5m has been provided in overseas aid to microcredit projects.
(2) Does the Government provide funding for microcredit projects in Australia; if so, what are they; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I have been made aware of the Minister for Foreign Affairs' statement on this matter.
(2) The Government provides a range of programs that, in the Australian context, might be regarded as akin to microcredit projects (described below).

The New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NEIS), administered by the Department of Employment Education Training and Youth Affairs, assists unemployed people to establish new businesses. The assistance includes a fortnightly NEIS allowance (equivalent to the adult rate of the New Start Allowance) for the first 12 months of business operation. NEIS also provides training in small business management and mentor advice

The Self Employment Development Scheme, administered by Centrelink, exempts social security recipients from the requirement that they search for work whilst they develop business proposals. It is also possible for unemployed people to be provided with an up-front advance of their NewStart allowance (up to $500) which could be used to finance a new business. The advance is repayable over a period of 6 months.

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission's (ATSIC) Indigenous Business Incentive Program may provide grants (up to $10,000) to enable Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to establish small scale business. A prerequisite to funding is that clients must complete NEIS or other appropriate training. I ATSIC may also provide temporary, fixed term (up to 12 months) wage subsidy grants to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander individuals and corporations during the initial establishment phase of a business enterprise.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 1 October 1997:

question.para: (1) How many (a) take-offs and (b) landings have occurred at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport in each year since 1990
(2) What measures has the Government taken to change take-off and flight path routes and procedures at the airport since March 1996.
(3) What effect have the changes had on (a) holding patterns and (b) noise above and near the airport
(4) Is he able to say whether the changes have added to or diminished costs to airlines: if so, by what sum.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The total number of movements at Sydney Airport for each calendar year from 1990 are as follows: 1990â201,966; 1991â216,030; 1992â225,582; 1993â241,377; 1994â251,147; 1995â263,212; 1996â276,977.
A breakdown into precise numbers of landings and take-offs is unavailable.

(2) The Government has introduced new runway operating modes to significantly increase the use of the east-west runway. Take-offs to the north from the new parallel runway with an early easterly turn have been introduced and the flight corridors to the north of the Airport abolished. The Sydney Airport Long Term Operating Plan has been developed and is now being progressively implemented. New departure flight paths designed to maximise overflight of non residential areas, or spread the noise where overflight of residential areas cannot be avoided, were introduced on 4 December 1997. New arrival flight paths will be introduced in 1998.

(3) (a) Major airline information indicates that excess airborne congestion time in the calender year 1996 was cut by more than 70 per cent compared to 1995 and was projected to have been cut further in 1997 to around one quarter of levels experienced in 1994/1995.

(b) Consistent with the Government's noise sharing policy, noise exposure over areas to the north of the Airport which had previously borne the brunt of aircraft noise has been reduced while there has been an increase in noise exposure for suburbs to the east and west of the Airport.
(4) I understand that reductions in congestion have led to significant cost savings to the airlines as compared with the period when the Airport was running as a `parallel runway' system.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the 1996-97 report of the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) and the importance placed on the integrity of the market by the exchange.

(2) Does the ASX indicate on page 26 of its report that the reduction in funding for the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) from $104m in 1997-98 to $74m in 1999 may lead to the impairment of its ability to investigate cases of market malpractice and initiate prosecutions where appropriate.
(3) What steps is he taking to ensure that the ASC continues to act as an effective watchdog over share transactions.
(4) Will demutualisation of the ASX require legislation; if so, when will the legislation be introduced into the Parliament.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) The figures mentioned in the ASX report are not correct. The Budget documentation for 1997-98 indicates an appropriation for the current year (excluding plant and equipment) of $119.398m and an anticipated appropriation for 1999-2000 of $104.987m.
(3) Enforcement remains at the core of the ASC's activities and its role under the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 remains unchanged.
I remain confident of the ASC's ability to investigate cases of market malpractice and initiate prosecutions where appropriate.

You should also note that it is the ASX which is the front line regulator of the day to day operations of the market. The ASX, in making and administering its listing rules regulating listed companies, occupies a formal statutorily recognised position in the system of co-regulation of companies and securities with the ASC.
(4) Yes. The Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997 was introduced in the Senate on 19 November 1997.

subdebateinfo.title: Stamp Duty of Share Transactions: Study
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2347)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a study conducted by Mr M. Aitken and Mr P. Swan from the University of Sydney concerning the impact of the Queensland Government's 1995 decision to cut stamp duty on share transactions.
(2) Has the Queensland Government action resulted in greatly reduced State government revenues, but a boost to Federal Government capital gains revenue.

(3) Is he able to say whether the study found that the cost to State and Federal revenue of the stamp duty reduction was $4.7 billion; if so, are these figures supported by research carried out by his Department.

(4) Has the Queensland Government stamp duty reduction, and its consequent impact on government revenue, led to discussions between him and State governments about Federal-State financial arrangements.
(5) Has he implemented arrangements to compensate the States for the shift in revenue flow from State governments to the Federal Government.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) and (3) Stamp duty receipts from transactions in shares and marketable securities are a relatively minor component of State and Territory own source revenue. For the three largest StatesâNew South Wales, Victoria and Queenslandâthey accounted for 2.5 per cent of combined general government own source revenue in 1994-95.
The Government is not in a position to verify the study's estimate of the net present value of the reduction in State and Territory revenue due to lower rates of stamp duty on share transactions.
It is not possible to isolate the effects of the reduced stamp duty rates from other factors affecting Commonwealth capital gains tax receipts.

(4) No. However, the Government has made it clear that reform of Commonwealth-State financial relations must be addressed as part of the taxation reform process. A Special Premiers' Conference was held on 6 November 1997 to discuss the Commonwealth-State aspects of taxation reform.
(5) No. Discretionary State tax changes frequently affect Commonwealth tax receiptsânegatively as well as positivelyâwithout giving rise to questions of compensation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 21 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Did Australia ratify ILO Convention 158 (Termination of Employment Convention 1982) on 26 February 1993.
(2) Is he able to say what action has been taken by Australian parliaments and governments to comply with the requirements of the Convention.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. ILO Convention No 158, Termination of Employment, 1982, came into force for Australia on 26 February 1994.

(2) Australia reports regularly to the International Labour Organisation (ILO) on the application of ratified Conventions. These reports include information on legislative and other measures taken by the Commonwealth and, where appropriate, the State/Territory Governments to give effect to the provisions of the relevant Conventions.

Since ratification, Australia has submitted two detailed reports to the ILO on Convention 158. As it would be impracticable to include the texts of these reports in this response, I have provided copies to Mr McClelland. Copies are also available on request to the Standards Policy Branch of my Department.

With respect to Commonwealth actions, the object of the termination of employment provisions introduced into the Industrial Relations Act 1988 by the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993 was to give effect, or give further effect, to Convention 158 and the associated Termination of Employment Recommendation, 1982 (Recommendation No. 166), and the object of the termination of employment provisions of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 as amended by the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996 includes, assisting in giving effect to Convention 158.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: Was the 11 p.m. curfew breached at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport on 4 September 1997; if so, (a) what were the circumstances of the breach and (b) is action being taken to prosecute the breach; if so, what.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Airservices Australia has advised that an aircraft departed Sydney Airport at 10:49 p.m. on 4 September 1997. This movement may have been in contravention of the Sydney Airport Curfew Act 1995. The Department of Transport and Regional Development is seeking further information on the incident from the operator involved.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: (1) In the period since the Long Term Operating Plan for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport was adopted, have westerly take offs occurred from runway 25 which could otherwise have taken off in a southerly direction over Botany Bay given the prevailing wind and weather conditions: if so, how many of those take offs have occurred.
(2) Are there safety implications for planes taking off over residential areas instead of over water; if so, why were the aircraft referred to in part (1) not directed to take off over Botany Bay.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. It is not possible to reliably estimate how many aircraft that departed on Runway 25 could have taken off in a southerly direction.
(2) The Civil Aviation Safety Authority advises that the risk of accident to an aircraft is essentially no different whether it takes off over a residential area or over water.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 20 October 1997

question.para: (1) Has the Government relaxed visa requirements for certain countries since March 1996; if so, which countries.
(2) How many on-shore refugee applications has Australia received since October 1996 and what were the countries and nationalities involved.
(3) Has he received or requested advice from his Department on whether the changes to the visa system since the 1996 Federal election have had an effect on applications for on-shore refugee status.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Government has not relaxed visa requirements for any countries since March 1996. A universal visa system for entry to Australia remains in place, as it was before that date, under which all foreign citizens seeking to enter or remain in Australia must meet the criteria for a visa as set out in the Migration Act and Regulations. However the processes used to issue visas continue to change and adapt to keep step with the growth in applications for visitor visas. For example, the Electronic Travel Authority (ETA) was introduced in Singapore in September 1996 and has since been made available to 26 other low risk nationalities. The ETA is not available in countries where experience indicates a high risk of overstay.

Prior to the implementation of ETA arrangements were introduced for authorised travel agents to receive visitor visa applications. Details of these applications are forwarded by fax to the responsible DIMA post for approval by an authorised officer. The performance of agents participating in these arrangements is subject to close monitoring procedures. In many cases these agency arrangements have been superseded by the ETA.

(2) From 1 October 1996 to 30 September 1997, 10,715 protection visa applications were lodged. The ten top source countries for protection visa applications were: Indonesia 1589, the Philippines 1451, Sri Lanka 1330, the Peoples Republic of China 1314, India 362, Colombia 285, Thailand at 277, Lebanon 261, Turkey 205 and Fiji 204. Citizens of these countries are not eligible to obtain ETAs to travel to Australia.

(3) I have received advice from my Department on the operation of visa processes, and on the factors which affect applications for on-shore protection. As I announced on 25 June 1997 the Government has also introduced a number of mea sures to address the abuse of on-shore refugee application procedures. These include:
. limitations to work rights for people making protection visa applications
. introduction of a post-decision fee of $1,000 for unsuccessful Refugee Review Tribunal applications.

These measures will act as a disincentive for people who are trying to extend their stay in Australia or who have overstayed their visa and are simply abusing the system by making non bona fide applications.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a recent report by BIS Shrapnel entitled "State economic prospects 1997-2001" which predicted that the rate of economic development in Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory will greatly exceed the rate of growth in other States during that period.
(2) Will he provide a special range of assistance measures to those States facing slower growth prospects over the next five years.
(3) Will he raise the report with the Victorian Government and discuss what steps can be taken to ensure the report's prediction of higher than average unemployment in Victoria is not realised.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. BIS Shrapnel has advised that its study, "State Economic Prospects 1997-2012", suggests that, in the five year period to 2002, average annual growth rates in Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory are likely to exceed those of the other States.

(2) and (3) Variations in growth rates between States will occur for a range of reasons, including structural and demographic factors, demand patterns and the policy measures implemented by individual State governments. It should be recognised that considerable uncertainty attaches to long term growth forecasts. The Commonwealth Government's economic policies are directed at improving living standards for all Australians through providing the environment for strong economic growth and sustained reductions in unemployment.

The Commonwealth provides substantial financial assistance to the States and Territoriesâexpected to total $35 billion in 1997-98âin the form of general revenue assistance and specific purpose payments. The States and Territories will also benefit from major Commonwealth initiatives such as the Natural Heritage Trust, the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund, and the Federation Fund. Where appropriate, Commonwealth outlays take into account the needs of particular regions.

subdebateinfo.title: Reserve Bank of Australia Board: Duties
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2361)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Does the Reserve Bank Act require the duties of the board to be listed in its annual report; if so, did the 1996-97 annual report of the Reserve Bank of Australia feature those duties; if not, why not.
(2) Did the Reserve Bank delete references to the duties at his or his Department's request; if so, why; if not, did the Reserve Bank seek his approval to make the change.
(3) Has he made announcements concerning the future of the Australian banking industry; if so, will the Reserve Bank Act be amended; if so, when.
(4) Will parts of the Reserve Bank Act (a) concerning the duties of the bank and (b) containing references to the maintenance of full employment, be amended.

(5) Is the statement on the conduct of monetary policy which was published in the Reserve Bank's annual report a proper substitute for the previous descriptions of the bank's duties; if so, why does the statement confine itself to monetary policy and price stability.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The only section of the Reserve Bank Act 1959 that specifies matters for inclusion in the Reserve Bank's Annual Report is section 81. I draw the honourable member's attention to it.
(2) No. The Reserve Bank does not seek approval from myself or my Department about the content or style of its Annual Report.
(3) On 2 September 1997 I announced the Government's comprehensive response to the Final Report of the Financial System Inquiry.

The Government has agreed to the Inquiry's recommendations for a new regulatory structure. Subject in part to the agreement of the States and Territories, this would involve replacing the present institutional regulators with three agencies established along regulatory-objective (or functional) lines:
. the Reserve Bank of Australia will be strengthened and its role focused on the objectives of monetary policy, overall financial system stability and regulation of the payments system;

. an Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) will be established to prudentially supervise banks and other deposit taking institutions, life and general insurance companies, and superannuation funds; and
. an Australian Corporations and Financial Services Commission (ACFSC) will be established to cover market integrity, disclosure and other consumer protection issues across the financial sector.
Implementation of these regulatory changes will necessitate changes to a number of Acts, including the Reserve Bank Act. Legislative measures will be introduced as early as possible in 1998.
(4) The Reserve Bank Act 1959 will be amended to reflect the Government's response to the Final Report of the Financial System Inquiry.
(5) The Statement on the Conduct of Monetary Policy does not conflict with, or substitute for, the responsibilities of the Board, under the Reserve Bank Act.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Does his Department's 1997 Winter Roundup concede spending cuts have contributed to Australia's unemployment problem.
(2) What impact did Government spending cuts have on economic growth in Australia between March 1996 and August 1997.

(3) Did the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia state to a Melbourne conference on 4 September 1997 that the growing complexity of the economy meant that different sectors would increasingly behave differently; if so, what steps have been taken to adjust his Department's analysis of economic activity and its forecasting.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. The Treasury's Winter 1997 Economic Roundup does not make this conclusion.

(2) The primary goal of the Government's fiscal strategy is to lift the level of national saving by increasing public saving. This will reduce upward pressure on the current account deficit and raise longer-term growth prospects, thereby allowing unemployment to be reduced on a sustainable basis.
The possible impacts of fiscal consolidation on economic activity were detailed in the 1996-97 Budget.
(3) The published text of the Deputy Governor's speech does not include this statement.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: Did he meet with a Japanese trade mission which visited Australia in the second week of September 1997; if not, was he given the opportunity to meet with the delegation; if so, why did he choose not to meet with the members of the delegation.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Details of my meeting arrangements are not the business of the Member for Wills.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a recent report by the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants showing the cost to small business of running do-it-yourself superannuation schemes is set to increase markedly in 1997.
(2) Is the forecast of $30 million in additional costs for small business accurate.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) The Government does not consider the forecast accurately reflects the results of this survey. For example, the estimate fails to take into account the finding that fees would increase according to only 50 per cent of respondents. The Government is unable to comment on the accuracy of the survey itself.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Do employment figures show a seasonally adjusted fall in employment of 32 800 for August 1997; if so, how does the figure correspond with the Government's employment projections for 1997-98.
(2) Are the Government's targets for employment growth and unemployment attainable.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) Employment fell by 38 100 persons in seasonally adjusted terms in August 1997. This fall was followed by a rise in employment of 74 700 persons in September and a fall of 200 persons in October.

Employment outcomes in the first four months of this financial year are consistent with the Budget forecast of 2Â¼ per cent growth through the year to the June quarter 1998. However, as stated in my 31 July address to the Economic Society of Victoria's Forecasting Conference, year-average growth in employment in 1997-98 will be lowered by the weak outcomes in the first half of 1997.

Forecast employment growth over the remainder of 1997-98 is consistent with reducing the unemployment rate from 8.4 per cent in October to around 8 per cent, as forecast in the Budget, by the June quarter 1998.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a working paper outlining taxation option, drafted for State Premiers which will be discussed at the Council of Australian Governments meeting in November 1997.
(2) If so, had he seen the paper prior to 10 October 1997.
(3) Has his Department made a submission concerning the working paper.
(4) Has his attention also been drawn to reports that one option contained in the paper is for the States to introduce a value added tax of up to 20.8%; if so, does he support the move.
(5) Is he able to say whether the working paper will be considered by the Prime Minister's tax taskforce.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1â5) The Government does not provide a running commentary on media reports.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a speech by the Commissioner of Taxation in which the Commissioner indicated a strong desire to crack down on tax avoidance through the use of trusts.
(2) Did his office consult with the office of the Commissioner of Taxation prior to the Commissioner's speech being delivered.

(3) Did he state in the 1997-98 Budget that the Government is concerned to ensure that trusts cannot be used for tax avoidance or undue tax minimisation; if so, does he remain committed to that objective.
(4) How will trusts which are used for small business be treated.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) I refer you to my answer on 1 October 1997 (Hansard , p8626).

(3) Yes. In the 1997-98 Budget, I announced that the Government was concerned to ensure that the taxation provisions relating to trusts deal appropriately with the modern day usage of trusts and do not permit tax avoidance or undue tax minimisation.
(4) I refer you to the answer to question 3.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: (1) To what extent are the Government's intended reforms of Australia's taxation system dependent upon the co-operation of State governments.
(2) Is he able to say what is the position of the Government of South Australia in relation to a Goods and Services Tax.

(3) In relation to State government revenues from gambling, is he able to say (a) what percentage of State government revenue is collected from gambling taxes, (b) which State earns the highest revenue through gambling taxes, (c) which State receives the highest income, as a proportion of total revenue, from gambling taxes and (d) what will be the State government gambling revenues in (i) 1998, (ii) 1999 and (iii) 2000.

(4) In relation to State government revenues from payroll tax, is he also able to say (a) what percentage of State government revenue is earned through payroll tax, (b) what are the rates of payroll tax in operation across Australia, (c) which State earns the highest revenue through payroll tax, (d) which State earns the highest revenue, as a proportion of total income, through payroll tax and (e) what will be the State government payroll tax revenues in (i) 1998, (ii) 1999 and (iii) 2000.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Prime Minister has stated that tax reform should include an examination of Commonwealth/State financial relations.
(2), (3) and (4) These matters are not the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Is there a timetable for the introduction of Accessible Public Transport Standards; if so, (a) what is it and (b) will it be met.

(2) Were decisions taken in relation to accessible public transport at the Australian Transport Council meetings of (a) 14 October 1994, (b) 21 April 1995, (c) 7 June 1996, (d) 15 November 1996 and (e) 23 May 1997; if so, does the Government support the decisions.
(3) What are the details of the process which has resulted in the development of the draft Disability Standards for Accessible Public Transport.

(4) Have consultations been held with consumers and industry groups in relation to the development of the Disability Standards for Accessible Public Transport since 1994; if so, (a) what was the nature of the consultation and (b) when did it occur.

(5) Has his Department's attention been drawn to the 1994 EPAC Report entitled "Australia's Ageing Society" by R. Clare and A. Tulpule; if so, has it considered the impact and demand that Australia's ageing population will have on public transport services.
(6) What work has been taken to ensure that Sydney's public transport system is fully accessible for the Sydney 2000 Olympic and Paralympic Games.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) There is no formal timetable for the introduction of Accessible Public Transport Standards, but officers of my Department and the Attorney-General's Department expect the whole process to be finished by November 1998, after completion of the draft Regulation Impact Statement in March 1998.

(3) The October 1994 meeting of the Australian Transport Council established a task force chaired by New South Wales to propose a strategy for implementing an integrated national approach to accessible transport; on the basis of the proposed strategy, the April 1995 meeting established task forces to develop standards and consider the financial implications; the June 1996 meeting referred the draft standards to the Attorney-General for preparation of a Regulation Impact Statement, pending which the States were to commence introducing accessible transport; the November 1996 meeting emphasised the need for the widest possible range of views to be considered in preparing the Regulation Impact Statement; the May 1997 meeting Ministers agreed to the establishment of arrangements to involve all stakeholders in ensuring costings used in the Regulation Impact Statement are as accurate as possible and in ensuring all options for practical and effective implementation of standards are considered.
The Government supports those decisions.

(3) The Disability Discrimination Act 1992 provides for rights and obligations created by the Act to be set out in more detail and with more certainty through instruments known as Standards. In transport their purpose is to set out how, when and where services should be made accessible, so that there is more certainty in planning new services, rather than deciding such matters case by case. Against this background, the Australian Transport Council established a Taskforce to develop draft Disability Standards for accessibility of public transport.

(4) Consumers and industry groups were represented on the working group which developed the Disability Standards for Accessible Public Transport in 1995-96. Since the draft Standards were released for public comment they have had informal contact with State and Commonwealth Ministers. They are also represented on a working group convened by my Department in July 1997 at the request of the Australian Transport Council to consider practical ways of implementing the Standards.

(5) Officers of my Department are aware of the EPAC report on Australia's Ageing Society. Public transport is the responsibility of State and local governments, so the issue of the impact of an ageing population on public transport services has not been considered in detail by my Department.
(6) How Sydney's public transport system copes with the Olympic and Paralympic Games are issues for the State and local authorities and the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: (1) When will the Regulatory Impact Statement for Accessible Public Transport Standards under the Disability Discrimination Act be completed?
(2) Has the statement been discussed with industry and consumer organisations: if so, (a) with whom and (b) were submissions received: if so, what was the content of the submissions?

(3) Are changes proposed to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission: if so, will they affect (a) the administration of the Disability Discrimination Act and (b) decisions of the Australian Transport Council in relation to accessible public transport?

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I expect that the Regulatory Impact Statement (`RIS') for Accessible Public Transport Standards under the Disability Discrimination Act will be finalised during 1998.

A draft RIS has already been prepared. However, at their meeting on 25 May 1997, Australian Transport Council (`ATC') Ministers noted that the costings in the draft RIS needed further analysis and agreed that costings should be based on up-to-date and accurate information to be provided by the States and Territories. My Department is currently seeking from the States and Territories the up-to-date and accurate information requested by the ATC.
(2) The development of the RIS is being overseen by a steering committee comprising representatives of the disability community, the bus industry and of Commonwealth, State and Local Government.

In addition, the current draft of the Accessible Public Transport Standards was released for public comment in June 1996. Information was sought from a wide range of persons, in particular in relation to the likely costs and benefits of implementing the draft standards. People were alerted to development of the draft RIS and were encouraged to comment on the draft RIS once released publicly.

(3) The Government has announced a restructure of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The re-organised Commission will be known as the Human Rights and Responsibilities Commission, and will consist of a president and three deputy presidents.

(a) The president, deputy presidents and the Commission as a whole will have the responsibility of protecting and promoting human rights. However, in order to maintain areas of expertise, each deputy president will also have responsibility for particular areas. One of those deputy presidents will be assigned general responsibility for issues relating to disability discrimination and human rights. The reorganisation of the Commission will therefore not affect the administration of the Disability Discrimination Act. There will continue to be a focus on disability under the new structure.
(b) No. There is no link between the proposed restructure of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and consideration by the ATC of issues relating to accessible public transport.

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Australian Navy Personnel: Malayan Emergency
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2378)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Were sailors who served on board Royal Australian Navy ships which carried out bombardments of enemy positions from within ten nautical miles of the Malayan coast during the Malayan Emergency acting under the Declaration provisions of "active service" as detailed in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of Thursday, 5 June 1952, and Thursday, 8 December 1960; if so, (a) was a campaign medal awarded, (b) was a Returned From Active Service Badge awarded and (c) did the sailors qualify as Australian veterans under the provisions of the (i) Veterans Entitlements Act or (ii) another Act; if so, under which Act and sections (A) were awards made and (B) did sailors qualify as veterans; if not, why not.

(2) Were the (a) Australian Army or (b) Royal Australian Air Force personnel who served in Malaya during the Malayan Emergency (i) acting under the Declaration provisions of "active service" as detailed in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of Thursday, 5 June 1952, and Thursday, 8 December 1960, (ii) receive a campaign medal; if so, (A) which medal, (B) did they receive a Returned From Active Service Badge, and (iii) recognised as Australian veterans under the provisions of the Veterans Entitlements Act or another Act; if so, under which Act and which sections.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a)and (b) No.
(c) (i) (ii) No.
(c) (ii) (A) Nil. (B) They did not qualify as veterans of the Malayan Emergency as they were not involved in operations pertaining to that conflict.- 2â

(2) (a) and (b) (i) I refer the honourable member to a reply given by Senator Newman to Question on Notice No. 314, Senate Hansard of 6 February 1996 page 235 and of 14 May 1997 pages 3133 and 3134, which was asked by Senator O'Brien concerning the Governor-General's Declarations. The Air Force Act, like the Naval Discipline Act, had extraterritorial jurisdiction whereas the Army's Australian Military Regulations and Orders did not.

(b) (ii) and (A) (B) Australian Army and Royal Australian Air Force personnel involved in the Malayan Emergency received both the Imperial General Service Medal 1918-1962 with Clasp `Malaya' and the Returned From Active Service Badge.
(iii) They are recognised as veterans under section 5C of the Veterans Entitlements Act 1986.

Dr Kemp

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 21 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Is he able to say wether an international conference in Lisbon on 11 April 1997 adopted the Convention on the Recognition of Qualifications concerning Higher Education in the European Region.
(2) What steps have been take by (a) Federal and (b) State and Territory Departments and instrumentalities for Australia to become a party to the Convention.
(3) What is the timetable for Australia to become a party to the Convention.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) An international conference in Lisbon on 11 April 1997 adopted the Convention on the Recognition of Qualifications concerning Higher Education in the European Region. The Convention (now known as the Lisbon Recognition Convention) was signed by twenty seven countries at eh conference and remains open for signature without time limit.

(2) Australia was represented at the Lisbon conference. Before the conference, Australia (through the National Office of Overseas Skills Recognition in the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs in consultation with States and Territories and the Australian Vice Chancellors' Committee) actively participated in the preparation of the Convention.

The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs is now seeking the advice of States and Territories and the Australian Vice Chancellors" Committee on Australia signing the Convention subject to ratification, and on whether there are nay legislative or practical impediments to implementation.

(3) The views of States and Territories and the Australian Vice Chancellors' Committee, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Attorney General and the Prime Minister are being sought. In accordance with agreed procedures, the Minister for Foreign Affairs would then submit the matter to the Federal Executive Council for approval to sign the Convention subject to ratification.

Following signature, the relevant State and Territory Ministers would be written to. The Convention would then have to be tabled in Parliament with a National Interest Analysis for at least 15 sitting days before ratification could take place. In accordance with agreed procedures, the Minister for Foreign Affairs would then submit the matter to the Federal Executive Council for approval to ratify the Convention.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Under what circumstances is a superannuation contributions tax payable.
(2) Is the tax payable by superannuation funds; if not, which bodies are responsible for paying the tax.

(3) Is he able to say whether it is common practice for superannuation funds to pass the taxation obligation to their fund members, if so, is the practice of passing on the tax to fund members contrary to the intention of the contributions tax.

(4) Will the Government establish guidelines to clarify the circumstances in which the tax is payable and the circumstances to which an individual fund member can claim a taxation deduction if the tax has been passed on to them by their superannuation fund.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Certain types of contributions, known as `taxable contributions', are subject to tax when paid into a superannuation fund. These include all employer and tax deductible personal contributions, specified roll-over amounts (that is, the untaxed element of the post June 1983 component of an eligible termination payment such as a `golden handshake') and payments of the shortfall of the Superannuation Guarantee Charge. A surcharge is also payable in respect of certain contributions made by or on behalf of high income earners.

(2) Generally, taxable contributions made to a fund in a year of income are to be included in the fund's assessable income for that year. In some cases a superannuation fund may effectively transfer its tax liability in respect of taxable contributions to a life insurance company. Generally, the superannuation fund is liable to pay the surcharge; in limited circumstances individuals are responsible for paying the surcharge.

(3) It is common practice for the trustees of superannuation funds to reduce end benefits available to fund members as a consequence of any taxation liability associated with taxable contributions. This is expected to continue with any surcharge liability. The Government believes it is appropriate for taxable contributions to be handled in this manner.

(4) The Government believes the circumstances in which tax is payable on taxable contributions is set out clearly in legislation. The legislation is clear that an individual member can not claim a tax deduction for any surcharge passed on to them by their superannuation fund. Accordingly guidelines are not necessary to clarify this situation.

answer.para: My Department is aware of a range of research assessing the linkages between workplace productivity/performance and different work organisation arrangements, including those based on consultation and cooperation between management and workers.

subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2436)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Is he able to say which states have signed the Unidroit Convention on Stolen or Illegally Exported Cultural Objects (Rome, 23 June 1995), and on what date each signed.
(2) Is he able to say which states have ratified the Convention and on what date each ratified it.
(3) Is he able to say which states have acceded to the Convention and on what date each acceded to it.

(4) Further to his answer to his question No. 73 (Hansard , 20 August 1996, page 3287), have Departments and agencies considered accession by Australia; if so (a) which, (b) when and (c) with what outcome.
(5) Have State and Territory governments, collecting institutions and other stakeholders been consulted about accession by Australia; if so (a) which, (b) when and (c) with what outcome.
(6) Must further consideration and consultation be undertaken before a decision can take place on accession; of so, what is the nature and expected duration of the consideration and consultation.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The following states have signed the Convention: Bolivia (29 June 1996), Burkina Faso (24 June 1995), Cambodia (24 June 1995), Cote d'Ivoire (24 June 1995), Croatia (24 June 1995), Finland (1 December 1995), France (24 June 1995), Georgia (27 June 1995), Guinea (24 June 1995), Hungary (24 June 1995), Italy (24 June 1995), Lithuania (24 June 1995), Netherlands (28 June 1996), Pakistan (27 June 1996), Paraguay (13 June 1996), Peru (28 June 1996), Portugal (23 April 1996), Romania (27 June 1996), Russian Federation (29 June 1996), Senegal (29 June 1996), Switzerland (26 June 1996), Zambia (24 June 1995).
(2) The following states have ratified the Convention: Lithuania (4 April 1997), Paraguay (27 May 1997).
(3) To date, the only state to have acceded to the Convention is China (7 May 1997).

(4) The relevant departments and agencies, including the Department of Communications and the Arts, the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade have not met at the inter-agency level to consider accession by Australia, nor has a timetable been established to do so.

(5) There is no timetable established for consultations with State and Territory governments. However, such consultations must take place before a decision regarding Australian accession to the Convention is made.

(6) Further consideration and consultation must be undertaken in accordance with the normal treaty-making process before any decision is made on whether Australia should accede to the Convention. This includes consultations at the Commonwealth inter-agency level, as well as with State and Territory governments, followed by the tabling of proposed treaty action in Parliament. At this stage it is not possible to estimate the likely duration of this process.

subdebateinfo.title: New Telephone Competitors: Electoral Division of Calare
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2439)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 28 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Are the services of new competitors in the telephony market, including Primus Globetalk and AAPT, available to customers in the electoral division of Calare; if not, (a) why note and (b) when will they be available.
(2) Is the Government taking action to ensure persons in the country have equal access to a competitive telephony system, if so, what.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The telecommunications regulatory regime established by the Telecommunications Act 1997 provides for open entry into the telecommunications market. There are now fourteen licensed carriers and a substantial number of service providers. The decision by those persons to supply particular types of services or services in particular areas is a commercial matter for them. I am advised that neither Primus Globetalk nor AAPT currently offer services in the electoral division of Calare,

(2) The current regulatory arrangements for telecommunications came into effect on 1 July 1997, enabling the entry of new competitors in all market sectors. The regime includes a number of arrangements which facilitate competition in both urban and regional areas of Australia. In particular, the telecommunications access regime, contained in the Trade Practices Act 1974, establishes rights for competitors to make use of the telecommunications networks owned by other persons in order to be able to offer their own services.

In addition, under Part 17 of the Telecommunications Act 1997 the ACA has determined that pre-selection must be available to carriage service providers supplying the standard telephone service. Pre-selection assists competition by enabling customers to choose alternative service providers as their `default' supplier of long-distance and international services.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 29 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports indicating that large supermarket chains enjoy an average tax advantage of $1200 each year over smaller independent operators, particularly in country towns and regional centres.
(2) If so, can the anomaly be corrected without legislation by (a) administrative changes to level the playing field for independent retailers and (b) changes made outside a review of the tax system.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am aware of the concerns of some independent supermarket retailers about the equity of the sales tax system. Because these retailers operate through an independent wholesaler, they may pay more sales tax than the large retailers which operates through its own wholesale/distribution centre. This is not a consequence of a higher sales tax rate being imposed on independent retailers, but rather a consequence of retail chains that operate their own wholesale outlets being advantaged by the status of the existing sales tax system.

I have met with representatives of independent supermarket wholesalers and retailers, including Australian Asia/Pacific Wholesalers Pty Ltd and the National Association of Retail Grocers of Australia. I have been briefed on the circumstances in which this problem has developed, and the implications for independent supermarket retailers and consumers. I have raised their concerns with the Treasurer. I am also advised that the industry has raised these issues with the Commissioner for Taxation by way of formal submission. The issue highlights the structural weaknesses of the existing wholesale sales tax system and reinforces the Government's determination to fundamentally reform the Australian taxation system. Had the system been reformed by the previous Labor government in its 13 years of office, this problem would not now exist.

(2) In responding to part (a) of the question, advice was sought from the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). The ATO has advised that the wholesale sales tax (WST) system is a single stage tax at the wholesale level. Sales tax is payable on the wholesale selling price (the taxable value). The WST legislation allows the Commissioner of Taxation to enter into administrative agreements with taxpayers concerning the calculation of the taxable value. I am advised that these agreements on taxable value are used in situations where the wholesale selling price is not readily apparent or capable of ready calculation. I am further advised that consideration of industry submissions is continuing in discussions between the ATO and industry representatives.

The issue raised in part (b) of the question goes to the very nature of the operation of the sales tax system, namely the application of a single rate of tax at the point of last wholesale sale. I am advised that any proposals for reform of the current arrangements are necessarily complex as they involve examination of a key building block of the current system and have direct adverse revenue implications.

As the honourable member would be aware, the Prime Minister has announced that the Government plans to reform and modernise the Australian taxation system for the twenty-first century. In evaluating the options for tax reform, an important consideration for the Government will be to ensure that Australia's tax system does not disadvantage smaller businesses and is conducive to growth and employment in this important sector of the economy.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Will there be benefits flowing to Australia and the Australian economy from the Commonwealth Economic Declaration, particularly with respect to greenhouse gas emission targets, following the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Edinburgh.
(2) Were acknowledgments forthcoming from Commonwealth countries in regard to greenhouse gas emissions; if so, what.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yesâalthough, given the meeting was not a negotiating forum and its outcomes are declaratory, the benefits are not strictly quantifiable.

The Edinburgh Commonwealth Economic Declaration will provide a boost to trade liberalisation by highlighting developed and developing country agreement on the need for and benefits of trade liberalisation. Australia's initiative to establish a Trade and Investment Access Facility under the Commonwealth umbrella will also help maintain the momentum for liberalisation by assisting developing Commonwealth members manage the potential economic and social impacts of trade and investment liberalisation. The initiative was endorsed by Commonwealth leaders and backed by funding commitments from Canada, Britain and New Zealand.

The declaration was also helpful in emphasising the importance of encouraging investment flowsâespecially through sound macroeconomic policies and financial systems, strong regulatory and supervisory frameworks and political stabilityâand the key role of the private sector in achieving economic growth.

The declaration recognised that the environment was a global resource and that the costs of protecting it should be borne in accordance with shared and differentiated responsibilities. This is exactly what Australia has been advocating in the climate change negotiations.
The language on climate change achieved an accommodation of the broad spectrum of different approaches to this issue. The declaration advanced Australia's interests by recognising the need for:
. all countries, developed and developing, to play their part in achieving reductions in greenhouse gas emissions in order to solve what is a global problem
. a successful outcome at Kyoto involving realistic and achievable goals.

Australia has consistently argued that an equitable, realistic approach to the global environmental problem of climate change should involve the adoption of differentiated emission targets, to ensure an equality of effort across all countries. Differentiated targets that take into account the characteristics of the Australian economy will ensure Australia does not bear a disproportionate economic burden.
(2) Yes.
It was recognised that all Commonwealth countries will need to play a role in achieving significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions. In addition, Commonwealth countries agreed to:

. underline the importance of a successful outcome at Kyoto, with all countries playing their part within the Berlin Mandate, with developed countries pursuing vigorously an outcome that would produce significant reductions in their greenhouse gas emissions through the adoption of a protocol or other legal instrument;

. call on the Kyoto Conference to recognise that, after Kyoto, all countries will need to play their part by pursuing policies that would result in significant reductions of greenhouse gas emissions, and
. call for agreement at Kyoto to arrangements to monitor the reduction of emissions regularly.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 30 October 1997:

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) No. There are no mandatory international standards. However, the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has issued guidelines which contain certain recommendations on cross-wind limits.

(3) ICAO guidelines cover matters on which ICAO member states have different needs and requirements arising from the individual states' operating environments. The cross-wind criteria in place for a number of years at Sydney have differed from the ICAO guidelines. If a pilot determines that, for operational reasons, the east-west runway is unsuitable then the longer north-south runway is made available.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 30 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1738 (Hansard , 28 August 1997, page 7369), what were the specified criteria referred to in the answer.

(2) What would have been the consequences of Captain Glynn determining that the east-west runway was unsuitable, in particular, what would have been the consequences for other aircraft waiting to take off or land.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Preferred Runway Selection Criteria are specified in the Australian Manual of Air Traffic Services (MATS). These criteria are used in conjunction with the Sydney Airport noise abatement preferred runway selection procedures in Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP) Departure and Approach Procedures (DAP) and the procedures on Preferred Runway Modes of Operations procedures contained in local instructions.

(2) Airservices Australia advise that Captain Glynn would have been sequenced for arrival on the longer north-south runway. Arriving aircraft on the east-west runway would have retained their allocated landing times and aircraft waiting to take-off would not have been adversely affected.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 30 October 1997:

question.para: Further to the answer to Question No. 1734 (Hansard, 28 August 1997, page 7369) regarding the number of aborted take-offs at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport (KSA) between 1992 and 1996, what procedures are used by air traffic controllers to accommodate aborted landings at KSA and to what extent do aborted landings complicate the orderly take-off and landing of aircraft.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Airservices Australia has advised that the procedures used by air traffic controllers at KSA in the event of an aborted landing (`go around') are specified as a standard missed approach procedure in the Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP) Departure and Approach Procedures (DAP).
The controllers also have the option of using an alternative directed missed approach procedure in the event that aircraft separation action is required with regard to other airborne traffic.
These procedures are designed to accommodate and process the aircraft initially as another departure and subsequently to further direct that aircraft to rejoin the landing sequence.
A missed approach has the potential to cause delays to other arriving and departing aircraft with the extent of the delay depending on factors such as air traffic at the time and weather.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 17 November 1997:

question.para: (1) What is the monetary cost of alcohol abuse in Australia each year and how does it compare with other industrialised western nations.
(2) What sum did the Commonwealth spend in 1996-97 on specific anti-alcohol measures, excluding health grants to State and Territory Governments.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Collins and Lapsley (The social costs of drug abuse in Australia in 1988 and 1992, 1996) estimated that the cost of alcohol abuse in Australia in 1992 was $4.5 billion which was 23.8 per cent of the total cost of drug abuse. I am not aware of any comparative studies internationally and there is very little data available internationally which measures alcohol related costs in a directly comparable way. Studies that have been done use different definitions, and contain different assumptions. Simple comparisons of expenditure are unlikely to have great validity, given the significant differences in health, social, and economic infrastructures and accounting mechanisms.

(2) Allocations under the National Drug Strategy cover all drugs including alcohol, tobacco and illicit drugs and it is not possible to provide a breakdown of specific allocations on a drug by drug basis as many of the initiatives funded under the National Drug Strategy do not relate to individual drugs but impact on the harm caused by drugs in general.

The National Drug Strategy does not represent the Commonwealth's total contribution to the problems of drug and alcohol misuse. The Commonwealth also commits substantial funds to the treatment of disease and trauma caused by the misuse of drugs, and for law enforcement and restriction of the supply of drugs including alcohol.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 17 November 1997:

question.para: (1) What sum was invested by the Energy Research and Development Corporation (ERDC) in its last full year of operation.
(2) What sum has been dispersed by the Government in similar grants since the abolition of the ERDC.
(3) What is the average monetary value of grants under the new grants system.

(4) Was a concessional loan of $62,000 granted to Neville Crocker Australia Pty Ltd to develop a single submersible light fixture by 1 October 1997; if so, what sum did the grant cost the Department to process.
(5) Are submersible light fixtures readily available; if so, what is different about this fixture.
(6) What sum does the average concessional loan cost to process.
(7) What criteria are used to determine if a grant falls within the guidelines and is successful.
(8) Did Transform Composites Pty Ltd receive a concessional loan of $367,582 for the development of the Phenolic Composite Panel; if so, what criteria did Transform Composites Pty Ltd fulfil.
(9) Was the intended date of completion for the Phenolic Composite Panel 30 June 1997; if so, is it now being manufactured on a commercial basis.
(10) Was Custom Ladder Company Pty Ltd given a concessional loan of $125,000 to aid its development of a mobile ladder; if so, what was technically superior about the ladder.
(11) Did Eski Exports Pty Ltd receive a concessional loan of $265,000 for the export of Tasmanian Spring Water Products; if so, what criteria did Eski Exports Pty Ltd fulfil.
(12) Who makes the decisions on which organisations are entitled to receive a concessional loan.

(13) Are decisions made by a board; if so, what (a) criteria are used for the selection of persons to the board, (b) are the qualifications and industry experience of each person and (c) has been the average length of time served by each chairperson since the inception of the new board.
(14) How many of the completed projects that received concessional loans, are providing long term manufacturing jobs for Australian people in new and advancing high technology industries.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) $416,705,990 during the last financial year (1996/97).

(2) I am unclear as to what the honourable member is referring to when he asks about similar grants since the abolition of the Energy Research and Development Corporation (ERDC). ERDC provided investment support for R&D projects in the energy sector. As such there is no similar program now operating. However, I note that companies that may have been supported through the ERDC could seek assistance through the R&D Start Program. Under the R&D Start Program the IR&D Board expects to approve around $120 million in grants in 1997/98, of which $18.2 million has been approved as at 25 November 1997.
(3) It is not clear what new grant scheme the honourable member is referring to. If he is referring to the R&D Start Program the average size of grants approved in 1996/97 was $1.34 million.

(4) Neville Crocker Australia received a concessional loan of $62,000 for the early commercialisation of the single submersible light fixture not for the development of the product. My Department estimates that it cost approximately $6,000 to process the application.

(5) There are submersible light fixtures currently available. Neville Crocker at present makes 3 models. There are also imported submersible light fixtures on the market manufactured in Germany, Spain, Canada, and USA.

The project was approved by a Committee of the IR&D Board against the selection criteria, which stipulate that a loan is for commercialisation of a technical innovation. Specific details about the innovative features of the product supported through a Loan are commercial in confidence.
(6) As noted in the response to part (4), it costs my Department approximately $6,000 to process the average concessional loan application.

(7) I assume the honourable member's question relates to the R&D Start Program. Applications for grants are assessed on a competitive basis by the IR&D Board against the Ministerial Directions. Ministerial Directions for the R&D Start Program were issued by me in December 1996, and amended in June 1997. The Directions were published in the Gazette of 18 December 1996 and 25 June 1997.

Ministerial Directions for the Concessional Loans for the Commercialisation of Technological Innovation element of the R&D Start Program were issued in July 1994. The Directions were published in the Gazette of 20 July 1994.
(8) Yes. Transform Composites Pty Ltd received a concessional loan for the early commercialisation of the Phenolic Composite Panel, not for the development of the product.
Transform Composites Pty Ltd had to rank highly against the merit criteria outlined in the response to part (7) for concessional loans.

(9) Yes. I understand that Transform Composites Pty Ltd has advised my Department that the Phenolic Composite Panel is being manufactured on a commercial basis. The company has advised that they have received firm orders for the panels which will be used in light rail cars.
(10) Yes. A concessional loan was awarded for the early commercialisation associated with the mobile ladder, not for the development of the product.
Details about the innovative features of the new product are commercial in confidence.
(11) Yes. Eski Exports Pty Ltd received a concessional loan for the early commercialisation activities associated with the export of Tasmanian spring water products.
Eski Exports Pty Ltd had to rank highly against the merit criteria outlined in response to part (7) for concessional loans.
(12) Decisions are made by the IR&D Board and its Committees, as prescribed in the IR&D Act 1986 and in the Ministerial Directions for the Program.
(13) Yes. Decisions are taken by the Board or by committees under delegation from the Board.

(a) The Board's membership is drawn from industry, academia and research organisations and its members' qualifications and experience cover a wide range of commercial and technical areas in various industries. When selecting members for appointment to the Board, consideration is given to:
(i) qualifications and experience;
(ii) geographical distribution;
(iii) spread of expertise already available on the Board.

(b) The IR&D Board currently comprises 15 members. Details about qualifications and industry experience for each member of the Board are set out on pages 4 to 7 in the Industry Research and Development Board's 1996/97 Annual Report.

(c) The IR&D Board was established on 1 July 1986 under the Industry Research and Development Act 1986. Since its inception, four chairpersons have been appointed to the Board. The average length of time served by them has been 2 years and 8 months.

14) The Concessional Loans for the Commercialisation of Technological Innovation Program was introduced in July 1994. The first project under this program was not supported until September 1994. All projects are supported for early commercialisation activities and have up to three years. Accordingly, very few projects have reached the stage when meaningful data could be obtained to measure their impact on long term manufacturing jobs.
