talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 17 November 1997:

question.para: (1) Did Sir Harry Gibbs, a former Chief Justice of Australia, recommend in December 1991 that legislation be enacted on the lines of the UK Genocide Act 1989 to implement fully Australia's obligations under the Genocide Convention (Paris, 9 December 1948).
(2) Did Sir Ronald Wilson, a former justice of the High Court of Australia, recommend in April 1997 that the Commonwealth legislate to implement the Convention with full domestic effect.
(3) What priority is the Government giving to enacting the legislation which has been recommended.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) I assume Mr Melham is referring to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report titled " Bringing them home". Recommendation 10 of that report states that the Commonwealth should "legislate to implement the Genocide Convention with full domestic effect".

(3) The Government has a number of priority projects currently underway in the human rights area and resources have been allocated accordingly. The enactment of Commonwealth legislation to implement the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide is not the highest priority issue for the Government at this time. As I have already informed Mr Melham in responses to similar Questions on Notice, the Convention does not require the creation of a spe cific offence of genocide provided other laws of the State party adequately give effect to the provisions of the Convention. I have also informed Mr Melham that the Government has been advised that the common law and criminal codes of the States and Territories provide adequate punishment for a number of acts prohibited by the Convention.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 17 November 1997:

question.para: (1) Does the Continence Aids Assistance Scheme (CAAS) only fund persons with neurological problems and cease when the beneficiary reaches the age of 65 years.
(2) What funding assistance does the Commonwealth provide to States apart from the CAAS to enable them to provide for the funding of incontinence aids.
(3) What financial assistance is the Commonwealth providing to assist persons with intractable incontinence who are ineligible for the CAAS.
(4) If there is no coordinated scheme to assist the persons referred to in part (3), what action will be taken to rectify the problem.

talk.start.para: âThe answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Continence Aids Assistance Scheme (CAAS) was not designed to cover all people who have a continence condition. The State and Territory Governments also provide aids and appliances for people with continence conditions as part of their broad ranging responsibilities for health and community services.

CAAS is specifically for those individuals who are eligible for participation in the workforce and for whom incontinence is the direct result of a permanent disability. This is consistent with the Commonwealth responsibilities for employment assistance for people with disabilities. Accordingly, CAAS does not provide assistance for people whose sole disability is incontinence or for people whose incontinence results from surgery, medication, illness or disease, or is caused through age related conditions.

Consistent with this labour market focus, once a person has turned 65 years of age and is no longer in employment, they are no longer eligible to receive assistance through CAAS. However, assistance is available for people over 65 years of age if they are in paid work for at least eight hours per week, receive an income support payment, and meet the impairment criteria for the receipt of the Disability Support Pension.
Similarly, children and young people at school are not eligible for CAAS.

(2) The States and Territories are responsible for a range of health care and other programs which assist people with continence conditions. The Commonwealth provides Financial Assistance Grants to States and Territories to assist with the costs of these programs. In 1987-88 responsibility for the previous Commonwealth Program of Aids for Disabled People (PADP), was transferred to the States and Territories, with a consequent increase in the Commonwealth Financial Assistance Grants.

(3) If a person does not meet the eligibility criteria for CAAS, then they may be able to obtain assistance through a program of aids for disabled people or through the public hospital system in their respective State. The eligibility criteria, and the range of aids supplied under state level programs are set by State and Territory Governments.

(4) The Financial Assistance Grants to the States and Territories provide discretion for State and Territory Governments to determine local priorities. There are no plans to initiate a nationally coordinated approach to aids and appliances for people with continence conditions who are ineligible for CAAS.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1997:

question.para: (1) Did the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Tambling), speaking for the Government in debate on the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Budget and Compensation Measures) Bill 1997 (Senate Hansard , 22 October 1997, page 7775), state that former navy personnel who served in the Far Eastern Strategic Reserve could qualify for full repatriation benefits if they met the same requirements applying to army and air force veterans and could prove that they incurred danger from the enemy.
(2) What requirements must army and air force veterans who served in the Malayan Emergency meet to qualify for the service pension.
(3) To be eligible for a service pension, are the veterans referred to in part (2) required to prove that they personally incurred danger from the enemy.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Army and air force veterans must have served in the Malayan Emergency at a time when either they or their unit were allotted for duty by the Department of Defence.

The criteria for allotment are set by the Department of Defence. Allotment for duty is a term defined in section 5B(2) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. A member of the Defence Force who has been allotted for duty, or deemed to have been allotted for duty, and who has rendered service in an operational area as defined in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, will have qualifying service for the purpose of a service pension.

(3) Any veteran who was allotted and who served in the area does not have to prove that they incurred danger. Allotment acknowledges an underlying assumption that when members of the Defence Force enter the area concerned they will be (or were) exposed to danger from the hostile forces of the enemy. However, if an individual was in the area but was not allotted, the Department of Defence would have to be satisfied that they did incur danger before they could be retrospectively allotted and hence have qualifying service for a service pension. As indicated in the response to the first question, the Government has agreed that the cases of any veterans, who believe that their operational service did expose them to danger from the hostile forces of the enemy, can be so reviewed.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 November 1997:

question.para: Have amendments to section 27F of the Income Tax Assessment Act resulted in persons being disadvantaged if they work beyond the age of 65 years because their termination payments are not regarded as bona fide redundancy payments for the purpose of a concessional rate of taxation.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: No.

Section 27F of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 was introduced in 1983 to give concessional tax treatment to bona fide redundancy payments. Under section 27F(1)(b), for a payment to qualify as a redundancy payment it must be paid to a taxpayer before their 65th birthday or earlier, if an earlier termination of employment date is customary in an industry.

Section 27F was amended with effect from 1 July 1994 in accord with changes to the taxation treatment of bona fide redundancy payments. These changes placed a cap on the amount of a payment that could qualify as a bona fide redundancy payment and made that amount tax free. Prior to the changes there was no limit on the amount of a bona fide redundancy payment and 5 per cent of the amount received was included in assessable income.

The amendment, in supporting changes to the taxation treatment of bona fide redundancy payments, did not affect those working beyond the age of 65 as such people have been unable to receive bona fide redundancy payments since 1983.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
